I should have left it plain because it was pretty good as is. They also come in very cute, instagram-worthy cups.

The baristas were very friendly and took orders and made drinks fast despite there being a long line. I was seriously impressed by their speed.

Parking around here is a bit of a crapshoot, I recommend parking 2 blocks down into the residential areas because once you past Lawton, it's all commercial area and all spaces are occupied and are metered.

I will be returning soon for you Snowy Plover!
author: Anna F.

description: Cozy little spot with good coffee and people. Tried the snowy plover since everyone recommended it and it was unique and delicious. I'll definitely come back when I'm in the area.
author: Char Y.

description:
Bright and airy coffee spot.

Soda bread gets sold out by 10am'ish.

Get the snowy plover--of course!
author: Yad L.

description:
THE BEST. Seriously, just the best.

The first time I tried Andytown coffee was on our IPO day - none of my coworkers (fellow recent transplants) had ever heard of them, but literally they all clawed me for the remnants of my delicious coffee after they had had a sip. I, in turn, hid the cup because I was NOT willing to share my delicious amazing coffee with them. Hey now- the cups are small okay : ) 

Now I'm lucky enough to have access to their coffee every day, and each and every single drink is as good as the coffee I had that momentous morning. I am completely obsessed with their espresso con panna. If you're like me and have a sweet tooth, but are worried about the excess milk used in lattes and the like, this is a great and wonderful espresso treat that feels sinful but isn't really. You get a warm, lovely espresso shot with a sinfully good dallop of (real) whipped cream. All for only 35 cals (or so says my Google search).

10 stars! 5 stars! All of the stars : )
author: Jackie C.

description: Good coffee.  Good people.  Parking can be difficult in the morning.   Line moves pretty quickly.
author: T C.

description: A friend told me about their Snowy Plover and it lived up to its hype! Definitely will go back again. Very friendly staff and cute decor!
author: Suprita K.

description: Best whip cream I've ever had. Their mocha was amazing, my only complaint is that I couldn't order a bigger one (they only have 1 size).
author: Silver F.

description:
Eh.
Fantastic coffee and great pastries. Minus one for absence of pourovers. Minus another one for typical San-Francisco-cool-coffee-shop pretentiousness/can't-seem-to-just-have-regular-old-neighborhood-friendliness-if-you're-serving-above-average-coffee syndrome.
Prices are high but I don't mind that because the product quality reflects the price.
author: Brian B.

description: There's so many things I love about this place, but the short answer to my review is superb. The staff is amazing, the atmosphere is dope, and you're really close to ocean beach. What's not to like? My go-to drink here are their lattes, but you can't really go wrong with any of their drinks. So if you're in the neighborhood, I definitely think this place is worth checking out. Bring a friend!
author: Keoni B.

description:
They changed their soda bread recipe. It's pretty mediocre now and takes like 15 minutes to toast some bread with a piece of cold cheese on it.

Their coffee is really good of course and comes out fast. Service is always friendly too. 

I'd grab a cappuccino if the line was shorter, I guess. The soda bread was my main motivator for coming back but not anymore.
author: Chase D.

description: Good little corner spot on Lawton. It's right next to a surf repair shop. They are very friendly and have good jade green tea. It's 4 short blocks to the ocean.
author: Ben L.

description: Super adorable cafe with plenty of street parking. Menu is minimalistic, but I still had a hard time choosing what I wanted. So obviously I had to head to yelp to see what I had to get. After scrolling through the photos and reading a handful of reviews, I got the Snowey Plower. Looked super yummy so I didn't question it. But in all honesty, I just don't get it. Maybe I didn't order the right thing, or mine was just made poorly that one time, but it tastes like sparkling water and cheap coffee. People complimented the Snowey Plower with how the sparkling soda does well against the bitter coffee, but I felt like the carbonation just took away too much from the actual brew of the coffee. 5 stars for service, 2 stars for my drink, so 3 (and a half) star average from me. Maybe I'll come back again and order a mocha?
author: Karissa K.

description:
Decided to try out a new cafe on this crisp Sunday morning to kill time as I awaited my boyfriend to finish an early golf session nearby. I miraculously find a parking spot near Andytown - which is already overflowing with people at 9am. The line moves very quickly, and it was my turn to order a almond milk latte sweetened with brown sugar. It was perfect. The staff are extremely friendly and helpful with answering my questions about the menu. 

Unfortunately, inside and outside seating quickly filled up and I was forced to return to my car. Luckily, Ocean beach is a quick 3 minute drive. Andytown's prime location makes up for the lack of available seating. 

Enjoying my not too sweet and still strong almond latte with the best view in town!

I think I'll just stay here forever and make my boyfriend find his own ride back home (:
author: Sophia M.

description:
Before T had become my go to person for food adventure in the Avenues, he wrote to me about Andytown. He said "Ms V, we should go there." He did go but not with me, it was with one of his Avenue lady friends, which, as I've gotten to know him over the years, is a thing that he's apparently good at: to have lots of non married dating middle age lady friends living in the Avenues. And with these lady friends, he tend to go to a lot of coffee shops, presumably they want to unload their dating stories to him. 

That said, when it was finally my turn to come to this spot, I was annoyed by the line out of the door syndrome. I understand recently some coffee place sold out its $15 a cup of coffee, this being San Francisco, is known to be filled with young people who like to line up for things that may or may not be mediocre. I completely understand that, I am not young but I have lined up like them in Tokyo for coffee zen masters. I understand it is part devotion part of mind body exercise. Good coffee require patience. 

Patience did not get me anywhere because I did not get Snowy Plover. What the heck is that? It's a bird. In fact, there is a sign by the beach that says it's a snowy plover protected area. But it's also a drink that everyone writes about. Cold soda coffee whipped cream. And for $4.50 it's a bargain considering some other place may be charging double.  Pastries are good, we got the last lemon curd scone. It sounded healthy at least. Cappuccino is comparable to Trouble. Not too acidic. There are little spots to sit and enjoy the coffee or the crowd, whichever you prefer, or you can do both, come to think of it.

All things considered, Andytown is better than Trouble for doggies. It has lots of doggie treats and a bowl of water. So when the next time I'm headed to the beach, with the doggie and not T, who occasionally behaves like the doggie (in the most enduring way I assure you), I'd come here over Trouble.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Delicious Snowy Plover - the whipped cream on top is so RICH + CREAMY. I could eat a tub of it in one sitting. I came to try this drink and it would be very refreshing on a warm/hot day but that is rare in this neighborhood. I will be back to try their soda bread. 

There isn't much comfortable seating to do work. One big table and some tiny high tops along the wall that don't get a lot of natural lighting.
author: Erin C.

description:
Walked over to Andytown to pass the time for our seating at Outerlands. It site on the corner of Lawton and you will know where it is with the A...and the long line. There is very little seating so expect to just come here to take to go or if you're lucky perhaps you'll get a seat.

We walked in and you smell the breads. Oh how I do love the smell of baked goods. The coffee menu is pretty straight forward and they also have teas.

I got a mocha and well although pretty, I felt it had more milk than anything. Yes it was smooth and yes you can taste the espresso, but a key to mocha is the chocolate and if there was chocolate or cocoa, it was not present. Perhaps I just got the wrong thing, but just purely on the mocha, it was just ok. I saw that they had this drink called a Snowy Plover, but it was just too cold to have a cold drink! I also would've loved to have the bread, but we were about to eat so I didn't want to spoil my brunch.

Perhaps next time I'll try it. I'll give Andytown another try.
author: Carolen M.

description:
The only problem is that there is little seating and it's hard to hang out there. It is very, very busy at all hours and consistently has a line out the door. It's probably because they make delicious things and are one of a kind in the area, although the prices are pretty steep. 

The coffee is pretty solid. Next time I'm going to try the snowy plover & a scone.
author: Michelle N.

description: The coffee did not disappoint! Also tried their snowy plover which was raved about in all the reviews. Love it and loves the more pastries. Will be going back soon!
author: izzie c.

description:
[Out-of-Towner Review]

I was hella skeptical!

I can't write anything different that everyone else hasn't already said. But just know that this place was recommended to me, as was the Snowy Plover. So I went on a whim, on our day trip, without even look at what it was before I got there. In line, I read what it was. Ugh. Not my thing.

I had planned to order a back up drink - a soy mocha. But they don't sell soy, only almond milk (the second time I ran into this in SF in one day)

This place is small. The kitchen(ish) area is large for them to make the coffees and bake the goods. There is a small walk way with some seating against the wall, all the way back to the restroom which has a barn style door. There is a large table in the front where people can gather around and share space. There is also a small coffee cart for everyone to use. They server all of their coffees and goodies on wood slats, super cute!

There is also plenty of seating outside of their corner location. Also shaded by trees, for the days the sun shines bright.

Back to my Snowy Plover. It was really good. Like, really good. The mixture of the S. Pellegrino Sparkling Water marrying with the espresso is a magical combination. I was worried about the homemade whip on top (lactose intolerance worried), so I didn't really mix it in with the coffee. I did just a little, got a hit of sweet. Something about the bitter of the sparkling water and espresso makes a slightly sweet and carbonated awesome liquid goodness. I don't know how they figured it out, but it works. It really works.

This was my only time here, but I'd love to come back and try their coffee. The employees were all really sweet. The one who burnt a batch of cookies felt really bad, since she stunk up the entire (really small) spot.

Snowy Plover, do IT!
author: Steph G.

description:
Quickest coffee visit I had in SF but perhaps one of the more memorable drinks. 

COFFEE: Got the snowy plover! Never had a snowy plover? Not sure what a snowy plover even is? Well, it simply is a mixture of club soda, espresso, & cream. Voilà! Snowy plover! Okay so it pretty much tastes like a coffee-flavored sofa with whipped cream. It's very strange at first but once you mix it and shake it up a bit, it definitely grows on you. It's a hit or miss but I enjoyed it's simplicity. Who knew those ingredients combined well. 

This was such a different part from the rest of the city. We were closer to the beach by the time we got here but we headed out to catch sunset by the 16th avenue tiled steps! 

Go ahead, try the snowy plover!
author: Julienne D.

description:
Cute little cafe near the beach. Good baristas and nice latte art! 

There is always a long line since it a very popular cafe, but the baristas are doing a great job at delivering the orders fast! Keep up the good work!
author: So P.

description:
I just left this place and I love everything about it ; the environment , the cleanliness, the friendliness of the cashier , the iced coffee ,everything ! I want to come to this cafe every morning and I don't even live on this side of town!
It's so nice to walk into a place and receive a greeting and not a stare down !
I will definitely be back !
author: LaNiesha P.

description:
Of the two Andytown's I've visitors, this is by far my favorite location. Not only is this the first location but somehow the Snowy Plover (the only drink I get here) is tastier at this location than the lab on Taraval Street. The espresso has a better aroma and it's slightly sweeter - maybe they put more syrup in their espresso at this location? ‍

Other things I've tried here are their scones, corn bread, thumbprint cookie and chocolate chip cookie. My favorite scone here is the goat cheese scone followed by the corn bread. 

They created a new drink called the Matcha Snowy. It tasted like seaweed and tasted better over time but we never ordered it again.

The only downside of this location is the line which never fails on a weekend and is the only time I can come here since they close at 5pm on the week days. At times, the wait can be 15-20 minutes just to get to the cashier to place your order. That's a bit too long for coffee that I consume in 5 minutes.

Love the drinks and food they sell but when I drive by and I see a long line, I won't bother stopping and keep driving.
author: Remus L.

description: Good hipster vibe coffee house ! I got the snow plow which is a carbonated iced coffee drink! Very original and refreshing. The pastries are really fresh and yummy too!
author: Mily W.

description:
GIVE ME ALL THE SODA BREAD.

On our recent visit to SF we stopped at Andytown for coffee and a quick bite. The line was out the door, but moved fairly quickly. We ordered a hot coffee and wheat soda bread with jam. Holy moly, I still day dream about their soda break - even two weeks later. Surprisingly moist, dense and tasty - their coffee wasn't too shabby either.

As Philz is known for their Mint Mojito, Andytown is known for the Snowy Plover. Personally, I wasn't a fan, but know plenty of people who are and live by it. Think fizzy iced coffee with heavy whipped cream on top. 

My only request? Please sell your soda bread by the loaf so I can take it back with me to LA. Extra things to know: they have minimal seating inside & out as well as other pastries and drinks (biscuits, muffins, cappuccinos, etc) and street parking around the neighborhood.
author: Juanita D.

description: We arrived at 0745 on a Saturday morning and street parking was easy to find.  There was a small line that moved quickly.  Customer service was great!  I came here to try the popular snowy plover.  I loved it!!!!  If I lived closer I would have one everyday.  The best way for me to describe it would be a coffee Italian soda topped with homemade whipped cream.  I also ordered an iced matcha latte and soda bread for my son.  Both delicious!
author: Tina R.

description:
If I saw the Snowy Plover ($4) from Andytown Coffee Roasters on Tinder, I'd definitely swipe right.

Made with Pellegrino over ice, two shots of espresso with brown sugar, topped with whipped cream that's made in house... this drink is pure heaven in a cup. Whether you mix the whipped cream into the drink or savor it towards the end, it will be a delight to drink. It is refreshing, frothy, and fizzy all mixed in one. Definitely made me feel like a little kid drinking an adult coffee drink! 

The store is pretty small, with a few two seaters along the wall and a large table next to the entrance. This is definitely a more to-go place! The line may seem long, but it moves fast. Grab a cup of coffee and take a short walk to Ocean Beach just a few blocks away!
author: Christine S.

description:
Line to wait... But nice place
Seems to be quite a popular neighborhood place. Lot of people ride their bikes there. The coffee was good and the food as well. There were some seats outside, luckily, because all the seats indoors were taken. I had some good conversation with strangers, birds of a feather flock together. I'd go back.
author: Phil L.

description:
I'm not a big coffee snob, so take this review with a grain of salt. For the most part, I just drink coffee for the caffeine, but like anyone else, I still appreciate a good tasting, smooth cup of coffee. My friend and I came to Andytown on a Monday morning and the line was out the door. The line went pretty quickly, though. I ordered the Snowy Plover (2/5) and my friend ordered a 3 espresso shots over ice (2/5). The Snowy Plover was very interesting. The coffee flavor was strong and smooth, but it just didn't quite work with the soda water for me. Together, they left a sour, almost barfy aftertaste in my mouth. It was pretty hard to drink. My friend's espresso tasted super watered down, but it was drinkable. Their saving grace was their super thick, rich, and creamy homemade whipped cream. Be sure to get this on any drink you order. I would come back here and try their other coffee drinks and their other baked items, just probably wouldn't get the Snowy Plover again.

Pros:
- Baristas were super friendly and helpful with their recommendations
- Relatively easy to find parking in this area 
- Line moved quickly and drinks came out in a timely manner

Cons:
- Not a big fan of their best seller, the Snowy Plower
- Espresso was a bit watered down tasting
- Not a lot of seating inside (more of on the go place)
author: Diana C.

description:
I am really surprised that I haven't visited Andytown until last weekend!! 

*SWOONS* It was love at first sip......their Snowy Plover is so good! Pellegrino, expresso and a dollop of heavy cream. 

I also tried their Wheaten Bread with raw cheddar and bacon. It was a huge serving and I had leftovers for 2 breakfasts thereafter. 

Friendly atmosphere and the line moves quickly. I suggest sitting outside and playing with all the dogs that walk by :)
author: Angela D.

description: Good coffee. Snowy plover is unique. Prices are incorrect on their website, really expensive for a couple coffees and two scones which were subpar.
author: Claire C.

description:
Update!! I went here again today while my boyfriend was at Lake Merced for dragonboat practice. Anyways, the line in the morning and afternoon was ridiculously long. The wait was roughly 10 minutes? but the line goes out the door. It's not a bad wait, but just be ready to wait! I decided to try to get the snowy plover and this was an interesting drink. They use club soda, 2 espresso shots and mix it with ice and their house made whip cream. The total cost was $4.00. I would recommend THOROUGHLY mixing the drink before taking your first sip! I first hated this, but it got better after I kept mixing it. 

I wanted to chill inside for a bit and use their free wifi, but I didn't want to bother the baristas for the wifi code since everyone seemed so busy with the weekend rush. I would recommend the shop to place the password somewhere, and maybe they do and Im just blind as f*ck. Anyways, as I stated earlier in my first post, the inside is small so be lucky if you grab a table or seats outside.

A weird observation while I was in line was that the girl in front of me got free coffee and food because she knew one of the workers. I know this happens all the time and I am not hating on the girl for using her connections, but I think it would be wise next time if the barista didn't flat out give his friend free coffee and food in front of other paying customers? Like bring your friend the drink toward the back or something so it isn't so obvious. I could also be totally wrong, but hey, it just what I thought I saw :p

Andytown is definitely a place I wouldn't mind visiting more than once and hope to try something new one the menu again!
author: Kenneth L.

description: Randomly drove by and noticed a line up. So we decided to line up too. Tried the snowy plover and was surprisingly good. This might be my new favourite iced coffee
author: Michael John L.

description: I usually hate scones and cheese. Somehow they manage to make an irresistible scallion cheddar scone which pairs perfect with their cappuccino. I find their signature snowy plower to be a little on the sweet side but its definitely something to indulge in once in a bluemoon. This is also another place on my "I have zero patience, but willing to wait" list because its just that good. Take your coffee down to the beach along with a good book. Definitely a winning sunday!
author: Rajeev B.

description:
Andytown is hands down my favorite coffeeshop in the Sunset. It's situated on the West side of the city, within a couple of blocks from the beach. Plenty of free parking around -- it's never an issue in these parts. 

The shop itself is quite small. There are a few tables lining the side of the shop and one large communal table in the front. There's some outdoor seating. I've only ever been here on weekends and it's ALWAYS packed. The line moves pretty quickly though. It's difficult to find seating since it's so small, but people come and go pretty quickly. So if you're a little patient, you can snag a sweet spot most days. The decor is very minimalist, clean, and modern. It's got a sleek vibe and hipster AF. LOL. I dig it. The staff is very friendly. 

SO FOOD AND COFFEE WISE. Damn. This place. The pastries are DELICIOUS. SO FREAKIN GOOD. I love their jalapeno and cheese corn muffin. It's the perfect savory snack. The soda bread is also very tasty. It's a super dense and rich slice of carb heaven. The coffee is pretty good. I generally get a cappuccino here. I've tried the Snowy Plover -- not a huge fan. It's like a fizzy iced coffee drink. If you're into the frills and whistles of hipster coffee, try it. If you're like me, and you generally drink your coffee black -- probably not a good fit. Too sweet for my taste. It's not coffee in my eyes. I prefer my coffee black and basically just an injection of caffeine. LOL. The blacker, the better. The drip coffee here is decent. My favorite will still forever be Four Barrel Coffee in the Mission though, so until I find a place that's on par with that coffee shop...Four Barrel will still be my favorite coffee shop for straight up coffee. 

Prices are average for SF coffee shops. It can rack up. By average, I mean pricy. SF coffee is pricy. LOL. But the quality of the pastries and the coffee is worth it in my eyes. That's really the main reason for 4 stars instead of 5. The prices are high for pretty good coffee (not "omg I can die happy and caffeinated because this is the best coffee of my life" type of coffee though, but close) but the pastries are clear winners here.  I think the pastries are what makes this place stand out amongst all the other coffeeshops in the area. I love coming here!
author: Amy T.

description: Tried the famous snowy plover, it was good but not amazing. The cream they put in there is what basically makes it good. Their other drinks seemed solid as well. Overall seems like a good place to grab a quick coffee fix. Not the best place to work due to limited seating, but I still saw a couple people with laptops doing their thing. They have a bit of outdoor seating which is good. Close to ocean beach, but it felt like this was more of a coffee shop for locals since it is a bit off the beaten path from main SF attractions.
author: Sundeep G.

description:
five for the snowy plover and mochas

what do i think of them?
for the snowy plover, i like the sparkling caffeination
for the mocha, i like that they use real chocolate
author: Stephen C.

description:
*UPDATE - I raised the rating from 4 stars to 5, as Andytown has become more or less my go-to, both at home and when I want to actually go out for coffee.  And that's even considering that I live near City College!  At home, we exclusively brew Wind & Sea in the mornings - we either buy it at Bi-Rite or at Andytown.  On weekends, we like to come here and drink coffee and work or just hang at the outdoor tables.  The line is crazy, but the tables turn over relatively quickly.  And it's only about 6 blocks to the beach if you want to take your coffee there.  I still don't love the scones, but they are definitely WAY better before noon if you're a scone person (I'm not - BUT, pro-tip, use some of the snowy plover cream on your scones!).*

This place is blowing up!

They were recently featured on some popular SF Instagram pages, and now the lines are extra crazy.  But I'm OK with that...

The snowy plover is total bliss.  I've had other coffee drinks elsewhere with seltzer water, but never anything with brown sugar and whipped cream.  The brown sugar is a nice touch - gives it sweetness with some depth - and the whipped cream is just crazy good.  It's so heavy, it's basically custard.  I love it.

The Espresso con Panna is also good, especially if you like your coffee drinks to be less sweet.

With respect to food, if you want the Irish Soda Bread, you have to go early.  They definitely have a good selection of other baked goods as well, but those start selling out pretty quickly too - and they get stale by close-of-business.  The scone that I had around 4pm on a Saturday was edible but not great...pretty dry and bland.

I have also been drinking their coffee at home and quite like it - we bought Wind & Sea, since I like the idea that they've analyzed all their beans and created a blend that they like, and I think it's on par with my favorite Blue Bottle beans (which are the Bella Donovan blend....and I see another reviewer agrees with me on the similarity!).  Definitely better than Philz or Counter Culture.  And - you can get it at Bi-Rite!

This is a bit out of the way for me, but always worth a stop if I'm out near the beach!

P.S. The space is pretty small, so not ideal if you're trying to sit down and work, at least not on the weekends...
author: Tay H.

description: Soda Bread and Latte. All you need.
author: Brian C.

description:
I really, really want to like this place because many people have said many great things about it and it is next door to the church that I attend, so it's quite convenient, but unfortunately, it doesn't live up to the hype for me. 

The place is a tiny corner shop with that often gets overcrowded by customers. It has a hipster, cool vibe to it that makes you want to sit and sip their coffee on a nice Saturday morning. 

I have tried their most popular drink, the Snowy Plover a couple of times, hoping that I will like it better, but I just think that the drink has a tangy-ness or a citrus to it that I tend to notice in the lighter roasted coffees. I'm not a fan of light roast or the citrus-y flavor that comes with it. I like my coffee bitter, bolder, and more robust. I think it is just preference because many of my friends like the Snowy Plover. I do think that their homemade whip cream is absolutely divine though! I would eat a bucket of that alone! 

Also, I don't know what it is, but their pastries don't quite appeal to me either. I have tried their sweet and savory scones, their muffins, and their soda bread and I just don't find that very good. I think it is the texture of them because they seem rough, dense and not light, fluffy and smooth like other pastries. I really do want to like this place,  I guess I just don't prefer what they have to offer.
author: Christina C.

description: Since moving to the Sunset district Andytown has become our weekly tradition. The snowy plover is my favorite, the fresh cream they add is such a nice way to start the morning. They do decaf espresso here, which is a big selling point for me (not for most, I know) but other coffee shops in the neighborhood do not offer decaf. My husband usually gets the espresso con panna (I believe it's called) or the Gibraltar and he's never disappointed. To round out the weekly trip we grab a corn muffin (gluten free) and head to the beach.
author: Kendra G.

description:
Andytown is exactly the kind of coffee place I was expecting to see in San Francisco, is the basic gist of this review. 

I really needed a pick-me-up after a late night out and an early morning, so when Christine S. and I saw an informational placard about the actual Snowy Plover birds down by Chrissy Fields, she knew that was going to be where we got our caffeine!

The shop is located in a pretty residential neighborhood. The baristas are super hip, polite but not friendly because they got a lot to do, ya know? The shop is VERY small, so plan to take yours to go if you don't see any empty tables. The menu is small but has your usuals.

And then the Snowy Plover. Sparkling water poured over ice, two shots of espresso added to that, and then a beautiful little quenelle of house-made whipped cream plopped on top. I don't normally like sparkling water, and I rarely drink espresso drinks, but the Snowy Plover is as good as they say. It is, after all, their only non-standard coffee beverage, and their claim to fame. It's super refreshing in all its fizzy frothy goodness.
author: Starr C.

description:
I was very intrigued by the snowy plover & its ilk, but for me, the concept didn't really work out, especially since the whipped cream stayed very separate from the espresso and sparkling water. The savory scone was outstanding, but the soda bread was probably worse for the travel, and seemed too expensive with the appealing-sounding seasonal spread of pumpkin butter and honey.

If this were my neighborhood coffeeshop, I'd be delighted. But as it is, I won't be traveling back to the outer sunset for it any time soon - which is great, because I won't be adding to the crowds, most of whom DO seem to be locals!
author: Lisa K.

description: The snowy plovers are good, but honestly I usually order a cafe au lait with almond milk and some super yummy baked good when I come here. The apple corn muffin is dooooooope. My fave neighborhood coffee joint.
author: Vanessa H.

description: Get the snowy plover. And get there early (before 10/11) on weekends to get the soda bread.
author: Aisling S.

description: The coffee here is pretty amazing. I came for their grand opening but got a latte which I have to say, was the smoothest I've had in a while. I have no complaints. The service is friendly and while it's also slow as heck (1 order at a time..?) I didn't have to wait that long despite the long line. Mmm I want more coffee!
author: Jenn T.

description: Great coffee and the whip cream is to die for! The staff is super friendly and make you feel like you are visiting old friends (especially the ones on Sunday mornings). Try their baked goods, you will not be disappointed.
author: Audra H.

description:
Andytown! A super hip, cute cafe perfect for our cafe-hopping-post-chill-Ocean-beach bike ride. I got the snowy plover because I wanted to see if it was all the rage from the other Yelpers' reviews. And indeed it was a delicious experiential drink!! First, you feel like you're drinking soda because of the fizziness, and then there's the bitter, rich coffee after taste. Then, you can spoon the salted whipped cream to finish it off sweet and to balance the flavors. 

One note is there's very limited seating, and we were there on a cold day and had to sit outside and keep changing tables to follow the sun. As we were throwing out the cups though, we noticed there were empty bar seats on the side inside! Good to know for our next visit :-)
author: Jenny K.

description: I live near Lawton, but never adventured to this place near Ocean Beach until my friend invited me today. He treated me to a strawberry corn muffin and a small hot chocolate. Fantastic atmosphere with seating inside or outside. We sat outside. It was sunny(not foggy). We had a nice conversation with some treats. Fun time!
author: Denise C.

description:
Coming here for the first time was the greatest decision that I have ever chose to make. Waiting in the line gave me the impression of how popular it is and I have to say it is pretty darn good to go there.

I ordered the snowy plover and a jalapeño and cheddar corn bread which was good, but I have to say that I thought that the cornbread would be warmed up instead of it being cold. Also on the other hand the snowy plover is strong and has an interesting taste to it because it is as if you are drinking expresso as soda.

There are limited seating, but I have to say that if you sit on the side you can see the other workers bakery the pastry which was a great thing to see because you know that it is fresh and not coming from anywhere else.

I recommend to give it a try! The blueberry muffin is also good too!
author: Brittany L.

description:
I had heard about Andytowns "Snowy Plover", a shot of espresso, soda water and whipped cream from a few people and thought that was crazy and wouldn't work. But it was awesome, basically like a coffee float/spider. Really refreshing on a hot day.

I also tried the muffin and scone. The muffin was super fresh, the contents still warm inside and the scone got a big thumbs up from the wife.
author: Tristan L.

description: This is by far my favorite coffee shop! If I could, I would drink it every single day! I love the Snowy Plovers but the Mochas are amazing. Every drink I have tried I love! But, they even have awesome food including the Soda Farl bread. They also have great gifts for every holiday. Andytown is great and the community vibes make it even better. Love this place!
author: Serena B.

description: The Snowy Plover Addiction is real.  Unique, perky, delicious!
author: Blake P.

description:
I absolutely adore this place. I go here every weekend. The coffee is amazing, and the workers are so nice. Some of them have my order memorized at this point. The pastries are worth trying as well! I really like the cheddar jalapeño corn muffin.

Only downfall is the size of the place. I would love to sit and do work there but it's always so crowded and there's limited seats. Also, there's always a line when I get there (which is good for them), but that means waiting outside a lot, which is frustrating especially when it's cold.

Overall, definitely worth visiting if you're in town!
author: Remy B.

description:
I honestly try so hard to go to other coffee shops when I'm in SF, there are so many really really great ones but absolutely none as wonderful as this. 

Only complaint isn't even a complaint, but a wish that they had a ton more space so that all of us that love them could sit around and gush about Andytown together while we drink our plovers and espressos... Good thing there's soon to be a second location 

Can't wait! 

Best spro
Best pastry
Best whipped cream
Feels good
Great team

Dream cafe
author: TC B.

description:
The wait is over! I finally got to try Andytown's! More specifically the famous "snow plover". Coffee with sparkling water and hand made cream. It was incredibly unique! The hand made cream mixed into the coffee was to die for. 
The coffee shop in general is adorable. They make all there own pastry's. My husband and me shared the biggest corn muffin with jam. 
Our friends recommended coming here before 9 AM or else it gets super crowded. It was crowded when we came but the line moves really quick! They have like 10 people working! Way faster then your ordinary coffee shop.
author: Amanda H.

description: Pretentious, overrated, overpriced. Wouldn't come back here unless I had a stick up my ass and a hankering for snooty service
author: Alex P.

description:
Espresso shot. Sparkling water. Whipped cream. Okay, is that it? I swear, there has to be something more in there, I am absolutely addicted to their Snowy Plover.

This intoxicating mixture has me thinking about it like as if I middle schooler day dreaming about my crush. Not only are their drinks amazing, their baked goods don't fall short either.

If you see soda toast on the menu, snag it! I've been there several times and only once was soda toast available. It is a thick toast submerged with lots of air pockets making it an extremely fluffy piece of carb covered with your choice of butter, jam, cheddar or bacon. Their muffins are extremely moist and they seem to always have it, that's a plus.

Andytown is quite the drive/uber ride over, but it is worth the trip to try something different!

*I have to say though, I have friends, who are like me, that dreams about their next trip to Andytown and friends who don't enjoy the concoction of a Snowy Plower. Don't knock it before you try it!
author: Winnie I.

description:
I've had Andytown bookmarked for years because it's always tough to make it to Outer Sunset. Finally, this weekend, I got to see what this Snowy Plover was all about!

* Despite being remote, there was a line out the door on Sat at noon!
* They serve a few pastries and a short list of standard coffee drinks and tea. Plus the plover!
* VERY limited seating inside, more seating outside.

-----------Snowy Plover Review Only-----------
I'm not a huge fan but perhaps it's an acquired taste - will be back to try again!
* Snowy Plover is, mostly pellegrino, 2 shots espresso, decadent homemade whipped cream
* Pro-tip: Mix the whipped cream in early, I saved mine all for the end.
author: Jess C.

description: Came here for some caffeine with a two of my friends. We left very satisfied. The place is small and the line can be out the door, but luckily we got there at the right time and ordered quickly. They are super fast at making their drinks which surprised me. They offer non-coffee drinks like teas and also scones, beer bread with seasonal spread, and cookies. I opted for the scone as both of my other friends opted for the beer bread. Those drunks, jk. The place offers seating inside and out, but it can be tricky to find a table when its busy.
author: Jesus C.

description:
This spot can be a little out of the way, but it's worth the drive for a snowy plover. 

For me, a trip to San Francisco is never complete until I visit Andytown. Their beans are also great - I order them online and have them shipped to Los Angeles between my visits.
author: Ann M.

description:
I googled an image of a snowy plover & the tiny brown & white bird is adorbs. 

Andytown's Snowy Plover ($3.50) is also a looker. Those enjoying their drinks "for here" get it in a tall glass. It looks like a root beer float or a frothy beer, except it's coffee. Rich brown liquid -- a unique concoction of espresso, pellegrino, & brown sugar -- topped with stiff peaks of handmade whipped cream. (I don't ever like the contrast of whipped cream in iced drinks so I opted for almond milk instead.) Fizziness reminds me of an Italian soda. Good stuff.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
What is an afternoon coffee?

To the soccer dad accompanied by his own mini-Ronaldo, the afternoon coffee is a sanctuary. The shot of Espresso is a welcomed escape from the other overly eager parents back on the greens. The Espresso and its invigorating aroma give him the much needed energy to enjoy the gatorade flavored kisses from his little soccer star.

To a college student, the afternoon coffee is a weekend luxury in the form of a Almond Milk Latte. The unassuming latte art complements her leather jacket perfectly to complete an image of a budding artist. The flavors are pronounced, but not overwhelming. The touch of sweetness from the latte is just enough to entice the college student to take her first step into the sophisticated world of coffee. 

To the loyal house puppy, an afternoon coffee is the flurry of relentless attempts at its companion's buttery Soda Bread. It is also a time to say hello to other dogs and lick the Barista. The last part is important because the Barista is known to have dog treats from time to time, and that would easily be a house puppy's favorite part of an afternoon coffee.

To me, my afternoon coffee is the Snowy Plover, an iced, fizzy espresso topped off with a healthy serving of whipped cream. It is reminiscent of a fifth grade root beer, bringing me back to a time when all my worries resided inside a Pokemon game. The jolt of caffeine reminds me that I'm now15 years older and none the wiser. There's nothing like pondering about life over an afternoon coffee.

What is an afternoon coffee to Andytown? It is everything. It is providing a place where a soccer dad can tune down with son. It is helping the student slowly assimilate to the coffee culture through the beauty of their latte art. It is giving a man's best friend another opportunity to hang out with the person it loves most. 
Finally, an afternoon coffee to Andytown is giving people like me a place to cultivate my ideas and write down my inspirations. This afternoon coffee may very well be the first of my many, many steps in fulfilling my dream of becoming a writer.

Thank you, Andytown, for giving us our cup of afternoon coffee!
author: Ringo M.

description: I have spent more time at this place than my own home in the outer sunset district. I love this place. Everything about it. I will support Andytown until the day I die. The workers are so nice and friendly, the coffee is great, amazing location and the soda bread with jam is so good I can never resist it. The inside space is very cute and small, however, there is a lot of outdoor seating to lounge in and soak up the sun whenever it does decide to shine in the sunset district.
author: Jenna W.

description: My husband and I visit almost every morning for coffee and a shared muffin. Chill vibes, amazing coffee (we normally go with drip or latte) and friendly baristas. Overall, great choice if you are in the Outer Sunset area!
author: Kayla Y.

description: Awesome snowy plunder!? Bacon and scone were delightful.... staff friendly and helpful! No wonder there is a line out the door always! Will return early for a hot roast and brm
author: Paul D.

description: Sandy Clover is a must try drink! Cool vibe, nice staff.  Intimate space, but still feels really open with the  really bright lighting/ big windows.  I'd head over again next time I'm by the beach.
author: Eric H.

description:
Two words: SNOWY PLOVER. It's a double shot of espresso topped off with sparkling water and a generous dollop of their homemade whipped cream. It's AMAZING. I will admit that this drink is not for everyone. I was skeptical at first but I'm in love I'm in love and I don't care who knows it!!! When you mix in the whipped cream, it tastes like an espresso cream soda! Sounds weird but it's so good! I also love that I can get this decaf, so I can drink it at 3pm and not be bouncing off the walls all night! 

Try it. It might change your life.
author: Taylor W.

description:
This is my second time here and the last time was a year ago. I'm visiting from Sacramento on a Thursday morning around 8 a.m.

Free street parking was easy to find and there was no line when I got here. The shop is very small, so it's not good for groups. Plan to either get your coffee to-go, or sit at the communal table up front or one of the micro tables along the wall. Despite its small size, the atmosphere is cute and enjoyable.

The last time I came here I still ate dairy and would of definitely given them five stars. On this visit though, I noticed that they don't have even a single vegan baked good option. I was also told that almond milk is the only non-dairy option for their drinks. Good thing I like almond milk more than soy milk.

I ordered the mocha w/ almond milk and was told the chocolate they use in it is vegan. I requested my drink for here and it came in a cute grey ceramic mug and on a small wood board. 

I would bump to 5 stars if they offered at least one vegan food item.
author: Regina W.

description:
Sweet Almond Milk Latte and Cheddar Scallion Scone.  Omg. 

I've never had a latte where I didn't have to add anything to it.  It was great!  For those lactose intolerant, this was a perfect choice for me. I had a sip of their popular Snowy Plover, but I thought the idea of having carbonated coffee was a little bit weird.  I was very happy with my sweet almond milk latte :)

Cheddar Scallion Scone - 4 stars - yum!  I love scallions and this was a great snack.  Took our coffee and scone to go and off to Lands End Trail we went!
author: Raquel Y.

description:
By far the best coffee shop I visited during my trip to San Francisco. I speak about this place with such highness, because the service I received was impeccable. 

Ultimately ended up going with a regular latte with three added shots (for the long, long, drive that awaited me home). The coffee was fresh and still fresh (despite arriving 10 minutes before they closed). Not only that, but the barista (wish I would've gotten her name), was so kind and helpful. I'm not much for small talk during ordering, but we somehow picked up a conversation, and she seemed genuine interested. Which obviously isn't a must, but it sure is a plus. She definitely represents the company very well.

I can't wait to come back here and try more stuff of their menu. Such a splendid experience.
author: Sarai K.

description:
If you want a unique refreshing coffee drink, get the snowy plover. It is original, delicious and you'll wish it came in a larger size!! It is almost like a coffee float in a way.  I also always pair it with their house made gluten free corn muffins. They change seasonally, but they are all delicious! Two of my favorites are when they have the goat cheese pocket muffin, or jam pocket muffin. SO good.  
If you go early early in the morning you can dodge the long line!
author: Rachel B.

description:
Snowy plover and whatever scone they have in season = must haves.

So the snowy plover...espresso mixed with soda water and topped with homemade whipped cream.  I feel like it's an acquired taste.  The more you sip, the more addicting it gets.  It was a mixed crowd amongst us but I loved it.  I'm a fan of all 3 components.  

The scones are also delicious.  They make them in house and are super moist.  Perfect pairing for your choice of coffee drink...especially the SP.  Ha.

How good is the snowy plover?  The person before us ordered 12.  Yikes!  The barista was super awesome though and made me my single order while they were working on the other 12.  Cool beans and 5 stars.
author: Jen W.

description: Andytown Coffee Roasters if definitely worth the trek to the Outer Sunset. You have to try the Snowy Plover if you haven't already and the Mocha is solid. Definitely ask for a scoop of the whipped cream- you will not regret it. The pastry selection is also hard to refuse so make sure to come hungry, too. Expect a line but it goes pretty quickly.
author: Grace L.

description:
Good: tasty coffee, cute shop, amazing pastry (get the muffin), ocean breeze!

Bad: pricey (so not Sunset), no cold brew.

And yes, their specialty drink "Snowy Plover" is worth a try. Not exactly something I'll get regularly but it is interesting.

Also, the muffin is huge. Easily shareable by 2-3 people.
author: Joseph L.

description:
*3.5*

Interesting take on coffee. I've heard so much about the snowy plover and finally had a chance to get one. One of my very good friends lives only half a block from Andytown so it was easily accessible since I was over at her place.

The snowy plover was beyond interesting. You can taste the quality in the coffee and the sparkling water adds a zing. It's like coffee soda if there were such a thing. It was something to get used to in the first few sips. I ended up mixing the whip cream in the drink and it made it a lot better. Their whip cream is phenomenal!
author: Tiff C.

description:
I feel like a Leprechaun that found a pot of gold at the end of a rainbow with the pot of gold being the Snowy Plover.

The Snowy Plover is espresso with sparkling water and a dollop of homemade whip cream.

First off, I hate whipped cream. And Second, I hate sparkling water.

But what is this espresso blended with two things I hate that is so magical.

I tried it in all variations. First, not mixing the whipped cream in then with a little whipped cream mixed in and finally all the whipped cream blended. In my opinion, I liked just mixing half the whipped cream. But their whipped cream isn't as sweet as you would think.

Don't skip out on their baked goods either. They're made fresh and delicious. The strawberry corn muffin was good, but too big to eat yourself. My favorite is the green onion scone which comes out hot and is not much of a scone but more like a buttery layered biscuit. SO GOOD. And don't forget about their famous soda bread.

Service is IMPECCABLE.

And don't let the line out the door discourage you. It moves by pretty quick and they accept credit cards via square.

The only downside is that I literally have to chase the rainbow deep into the sunset for some good ol' cup of joe.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Lines, lines, lines every morning.  Love their snowy plover and lattes.  This is a neighborhood coffee shop and is very popular.  Looks like lots of teachers from the nearby schools come here.  Snowy plover is the best here!
author: Gab T.

description: I like that! The baristas were very kind and helpful. Can't miss if you're in the neighborhood. They have outside seating and parking could be had easily for a place so close to the beach.
author: Bowen F.

description:
Simply put, this is my new go-to spot for coffee. No wonder people are lining up at 7:45am, fifteen minutes before they open. The coffee is is amazing, the staff are all friendly, and the baked good are as good as it gets. Everything Andytown does here is with care and passion. They use organic ingredients and in turn make high quality products that are incredible.

The whole environment of the place just makes you feel good. It's a rainy day and yet everyone is still here waiting to get in. The reason for that is because the second you enter Andytown, you enter this happy and awesome atmosphere where you feel as if it's not raining outside. You just want to grab a nice hot coffee, a pastry and sit down to enjoy it. The staff here definitely are a big reason for that as they're all very passionate about what they make. Coming here is more of an experience than just a visit. 

Also, make sure to try the Soda Bread and Snowy Plover. Those are 2 of the biggest hits here. Overall, If you're looking for an amazing cup of coffee and some yummy baked treats, this is your place. Yes, the place definitely gets packed, but there's no doubt in my mind it's worth the trip.
author: Alex B.

description:
Oh my beejeezus. This is easily my favorite cafe in Sunset. It is cute and hipster, but not pretentiously hipster (it is hipster, but not to the point where they make you feel unwelcome because you're not cool enough. In fact, the baristas here are so awesome & friendly). And while the space is small, they have one large table for groups and several indoor & outdoor 2-3 person tables. 

I typically get the espresso or Americano, just black. It's strong and smooth, aka perfection. 

If I'm feeling wild, I'll get the almond milk latte! A bit pricey, but #worthit. It goes down soo smoothly and has the perfect espresso:milk ratio. They use the Califia Barista Almond Milk blend (versus 'regular' almond milk). I do wish that they offered more size options (only 12oz avail).  

For the brewed coffee & au lait drinks, bring your own cup up to 20oz and pay the price of a regular sized drink.

No minimum on credit card. Very dog-friendly (they have doggy treats) :) And given it's located in Sunset, parking is not even that terrible (for SF standards)! Only thing is expect to wait at least 15-20 minutes on a standard weekend morning.
author: Samantha C.

description: Came here to catch up with some friends. Greeted by a line on a Saturday morning. The lines goes out the door, it's a small place. Most people grab their drinks to go, but we were lucky to share part of the large table inside with some other folk. Definitely not a place to come to get work done, but it's a pretty sweet meeting place. Good selection of pastries and baked goods to go along with your coffee. Found free street parking easily right outside! Friendly staff and good vibes. Would go again!
author: Meagan C.

description: My mom and I come here every weekend for two Snowy Plovers and whatever great pastries they have! Andytown is potentially the greatest coffee shop in the world, and not just for its amazing coffee. The baristas are so kind, the store is aesthetically pleasing, and the vibe is just great. I don't think I will ever find a coffee shop I love more :^)
author: Josie D.

description: This area is starving for good coffee and Andy's is the closest thing. Definitely third wave, definitely using good beans. I've been a couple times now and it is inconsistent. The high is a 4+ star, the low is 2. Definitely go here if you are in the area, it's the best around. Prepare to wait in line in the morning.
author: Stuart A.

description:
I can't say much about this carbonated espresso experience because that's what drew me here the first time. However, subsequent visits and a slew of normal coffee later is making me a huge fan of Andytown.

I really like that there is great coffee in this part of town now because prior to this, a lot of places here we just known for their boba, or great Asian snacks. I like that Andytown is adventurous, but I don't really recommend the carbonated espresso ... 

Either way, they have delicious scones, muffins and make a mean latte. 

They get super busy on weekends, the lines are always out the door!
author: Lorrie M.

description: I had a $4 Snowy Plover...it was okay...it's a drink that you needs an acquired tasted. I think it's ice cubes, expresso, carbonated water and a dollop of their homemade whipped cream. I think it would taste better if there wasn't any carbonated water. The coffee was good, the whipped cream was good but they messed it up with the carbonated water. If they didn't have that, that would be IDEAL!
author: Kylie L.

description: Snowy plover is amazing! Worth the trip to the outer sunset. Limited seating, but some outdoor seating as well. Nice little vibe.
author: Amanda L.

description: Very happy with this relatively new neighborhood spot. Friendly staff; maybe a little hip. Good unique drinks and snacks. I've wished a few times they had some more substantial dishes but I guess that's not really what they are about.
author: Dmitri H.

description:
Andytown coffee roasters is an awesome cafe . They have awesome decor and serve you everything on their fancy wooden boards. The environment inside is awesome and their staff is super friendly . It's pretty spacious inside and out with plenty of seating for everyone .  They have one giant table by the door and a bunch of seating along the wall .

I went around 3 and they were already sold out of the soda bread so we got the snowy plover which is their specialty coffee and a scone. The snowy plover is their coffee blended with soda topped with their homemade whipped cream. I know it sounds a bit odd at first but it's definitely worth a try . It definitely gives it an interesting flavor . The scone I got was sweet compared to the other savory one they had . It wasn't too dry like the other scones I've had. Overall this is an awesome cafe and definitely recommend checking it out. I'll definitely be back to try the soda bread and other baked goods that they had .
author: Thomas W.

description:
Snowy Plover = Mind Blown. It's soda water + espresso + something creamy = YASSSSS.

Cute spot near the beach. Perfect refreshment for a warm afternoon. I never would've thought to combine soda water and espresso, but it's a brilliant mix.
author: Drew M.

description:
Snowy plover! A full on dessert - a coffee cream soda! Apparently espresso has less caffeine in it than drip coffee? Great! Bring on that gorgeous whipped cream.

There are little dinosaurs in the succulent plants and also on these adorable big mugs they sell. Cool find in the middle of the Sunset.
author: Steph C.

description:
Cute, cozy, and popular coffee spot in the Outer Sunset. My friend took me here on a foggy weekday morning to try their mocha, and there seems to be a consistent a line out the door. Can't blame them! Their mocha is quite chocolatey and delicious. A little too sweet for me but will definitely please all the chocolate lovers out there.

Like I said, this coffeeshop is cozy. And by cozy, I mean tiny and claustrophobia-inducing. There's one table for multiple people by the front door and some two-person seating along the back wall. This place seems to be best for to-go drinks, though I've seen people with their laptops here. There's also some seating along the outside of Andytown where my friend and I sat. It's quiet and cold but still nice.

Next time, I'll have to try their famous "snowy plover" which is coffee with sparkling water and cream. That didn't sound appealing to me at first, but I'm down to try anything once!

EDIT: Tried the snowy plover, and while I thought the taste was funky, it had my wired for the rest of the day. WOW!! Not my style of coffee (it's basically carbonated coffee) but I know where to turn when I need a huge boost of caffeine.
author: Stefanie C.

description: I got the double minted rose and a raspberry muffin! I loved the tea, but mostly I like the atmosphere there. One of the women behind the counter who takes your order is really nice!
author: Chanel C.

description:
We had the Snowy plover, cappuccino, iced americano, strawberry chocolate scone, Apple corn muffin filled with raspberry jam and a curry vegetable pastry... Just yes. Everything was delicious.

The baked goods were fresh out of the oven. Coffee wise the cappuccino was by far the best, but the snowy plovers whipped cream is heaven. The drink itself is interesting, but try it! It's worth a taste. They were roasting coffee when we stopped in too! 

The apple corn muffin brought me home tithe Midwest and the scone was crisp on the outside with crystallized sugar and soft inside, perfect. 

The line was intimidating, but moves fairly quickly. I'll definitely be back!
author: Katherine R.

description: Me love me some Andytown. Just have to open one across the park in he Richmond District, that mile hike kills me  seriously amazing coffee and amazing goodies...crew is always super personable and nice!
author: N M.

description: Snowy plover!!! It's definitely what sets this place apart from other coffee roasters in the area. It's delicious and would be great on a warm SF day.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Absolutely delicious coffee and baked goods.  The staff is always so chill and friendly.  This place is super hip but not pretentious- definitely worth the journey to the Outer Sunset.
author: Lynn G.

description: If you can avoid the crowds, this is a delightful little place. Seating is minimal: four or five tables inside, and a handful outside on the sidewalk, but on cold days, they aren't much of an option. Andytown's bakers are outstandingly talented, as are a few of their baristas. If you manage to find a seat (odds are best on weekday afternoons), a muffin and a mug of their batch brew make just about the best breakfast you could ask for. Unfortunately, half the time I walk up, the place is full to the brim and there's a line out the door, so I take my order to go. I hate to do it with such fine coffee, but c'est la vie. I can hardly decry them for attracting customers.
author: Izana N.

description: Drove by early morning and decided to get some coffee. Cashier was nice and service was quick! I ordered a double shot latte with almond milk! And wow, let me tell you.. it's the best latte I have ever had! It was smooth, it's definitely quality coffee! I'll definitely be coming back to try their other drinks!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Cute corner shop! Friend introduces us to her favorite coffee spot, and Andytown does not disappoint!
There's a pretty long line on Saturday lunch time. 
Of course I ordered the most recommended snowy plover, even on a cold, windy and rainy day. I DO NOT REGRET IT! Expresso + soda + cream, who knows this combination is this delicious and amazing!? By adding expresso and soda, the coffee tastes a bit on the sour side, but the lightly sweeten cream just neutralized the sourness. 
Their pastries look amazing and delicious as well, along with beautiful serving tray and ceramics. Now it is my favorite too!
author: Ya K.

description:
This was the second stop on my recent trip to SF, and just one of a few must stops for my entire trip. I wavered between the snowy plover and a latte because of all the rave reviews of the plover, but I decided to stick with what I love and went with the latte. They don't have flavored syrups here, but they do their own in house sweetener, which I actually really enjoyed. I would highly recommend their lattes. They were out of all their bread when I went, so my friend and I shared a cheddar scone, which was still good, but I really wanted to their bread! Will need to come back for that, and to try the snowy plover.

Service was extremely sweet and courteous.

We sat outside on what happened to be the one hot day of the week, and I wish they had some umbrellas or something 'cause the sun was extremely hot. They have one large table inside, which I bet once you get it, you stay for quite a while, and a few tiny (and I mean tiny!) tables along one of the walls in the back.
author: Kathy L.

description:
This is honestly the best coffee shop I've ever been to.

(First Star)The baristas here are very friendly without the smugness you get at other coffee ahops.

(Second Star)Their drinks are the best. Try the snowy plover for their speciality or get a cappuccino with whip cream!

(Third Star)They use very high quality beans which you can also purchase for home.

(Fourth Star)Their pastries are on point. I love their corn muffins, pastys, and scones.

(Fifth Star) I love the beach side design and layout of the place. The smell of coffee beans and pastries are great. Seating is limited but this is more of a stop and go place if you want to do light reading.

Expect 15min wait for peak times during weekends, less so on weekdays.
author: James K.

description:
An (almost) perfect coffee shop! Tucked away near the Sunset, a well-lit corner shop that proves both classy and inviting. They clearly know (and love) their coffee. They clearly love their space. Certain coffee shops I've been to with this sort of style - the oh so perfect, artsy, creative spots - seem to make me feel uncomfortable, like I don't fit into the image. Andytown, however, was extremely welcoming. All of the employees I interacted with seemed very genuine, passionate, and super chill. The pricing is reasonable. Along the walls there are really neat artwork pieces, like the mugs. 

Hot cocoa was my selection, and it was made how it should be - with actual cocoa /warm milk and not some mix like chain coffee shops might give you. Rich, flavorful, and delicious. So perfect for the chill breeze of a San Francisco Autumn evening. 

The one thing that makes this place not perfect is that there is very little seating inside, one corner table and a few small stool type seats against the wall. It's such a nice place I really wish I had more space to sit and stay while I enjoy my drink. 

Overall, such a great spot - I'll visit again! 

(TOP 100 PLACES TO EAT IN 2015, #23)
author: Kailyn T.

description: This place is special. Stunning coffee. Pretty cool place for coffee. Not much space to sit and enjoy your favorite drink. But it is enough to relax.
author: Sophie R.

description:
I tried their Snowy Plover and thought it was quite nice!! It turns out to be their signature drink made with espresso, soda water, topped with some whipped cream. I do not like soda nor whipped cream, but I believe in Andytown and order it. Had a sip and was so surprised. Hmmmm the perfect balance of fizz and espresso with some creaminess made my taste buds so happy! Also had their pumpkin chocolate scone which was yummy, on the dry side but still with nice texture and not too sweet, pumpkin flavor is subtle and I think they used bittersweet chocolate. Cheddar and jalapeño corn muffin is the bomb, and I usually don't even like
Cheddar!! The top of the muffin taste like Cheez-it. I love you Andytown.
author: Iris H.

description:
Been trying to taste this spot for the longest time but it was closed during the weeks prior to the new year. So, luckily I was able to stop by before heading to work...with no line!! 

I got the Snowy Plover as everyone has raved and I definitely agree with folks. It's definitely a cool and different take on a coffee crafted drink and the experience really was memorable. It's weirdly refreshing with the pellegrino fizz mixed with the espresso. And the whip adds that delicious sweetness. I'm interested in coming back to try the pastries and other menu items too.

This was my first official coffee of the new year and if it's any symbolic indication of what's to come, I'm definitely excited!
author: Vincent L.

description: I love this place! the trees are great and the coffee is my fave in the city
author: Michelle C.

description: Stumbled upon this place on a trip to the City.  Everybody was ordering the Snowy Plover. When in Rome....  Later learned it had been dubbed the best drink in San Francisco by some local publication.  Not sure I would go that far but very different and tasty.  Plain old cappuccino is pretty good too.  Friendly service.  Only downside is the line.
author: Ben S.

description:
I tried the snowy plover because that's what everyone raves. It's pretty interesting. It's so unique like no other. But I'm a tad biased because I'm not big on coffee and I dislike sparkling water. Hence I thought wow, it's interesting. I can imagine most people will like it. I did like the cheddar scallion scone. It's got perfect scone texture and it's nicely warm and toasty. Taste was flavorful but light at the same time. I really enjoyed it. Overall the place was 4 stars. 4.5 for the scone.

It's perfect to get coffee then walk down the street to the beach but snowy plovers are prohibited at the beach. ;)
author: Arnold W.

description:
From one coffee addict to another, Andytown is the best coffee I've had in recent memory. Simple, chic, and locally owned, this coffee shop serves a Cafe Au Lait that'll keep you coming back over and over and over again. And, it's a fun way to meet your neighbors - the barista's and other customers chat it up like you are a long lost friend!

Leave your laptop at home, bring a fresh mind, and settle into a coffee, for here.
author: Regina D.

description: Tried the Snowy Plover & Iced coffee. Both great warm city afternoon drinks. Mmmm. Nice after a day at the zoo. Worth the uphill walk
author: Mr C.

description:
Snowy Plover.  Who knew sparkling water, espresso, and whipped cream could be so freaking good?!  You get the strength of coffee but the refreshing aspect of the bubbles.  

The baked goods are also superrific.  Pumpkin muffin scone, cheddar jalapeño corn muffin.  God I don't even like baked goods that much.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Close your eyes and imagine an iced Americano. 
But instead of water, make it SPARKLING water.

GAME CHANGER

Their signature Snowy Plover is like a coffee soda with their housemade brown sugar whipped cream on top.

SO YUM.

They also have great artisan scones, I recommend the corn muffins. We also got a beet & goat cheese one that I personally thought lacked flavor. 

As a strict black coffee-only drinker, I approve. Although I probably wouldn't get this on a regular basis. This is a coffee dessert treat fasho.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
This is everyone happy place. Consistently happy and friendly service! Place is super bright and clean. It's no wonder they always have a long line for their delicious menu and baked goods. Almond latte and iced coffee are my favorites. The baked goods change daily but are all always bomb!

Keep up the good work!
author: Ellen W.

description:
I've been to Andytown a couple times now and it never disappoints!

The most popular drink they serve is a Snow Plow - two shots of espresso, sparkling water and a huge dump of heavy cream. 

Very interesting drink, def. wanna mix it well before drinking it. 

They have a small roaster in the back and a very very narrow wall seating. If you're coming to hang around I suggest the outdoor seating. 

Great coffee and kind staff. Andytown is located in the sunset district, less than 4 blocks away from Outerlands, The General Store, and Trouble Coffee.
author: Brian L.

description:
I love Andytown. But there's one major issue... so does everyone else!

The first time I stopped by there was barely anyone here and the whole experience was awesome. The baristas were very friendly and quick with making an awesome mocha with almond milk. The atmosphere was cool with minimal seating (it's a small shop) and not far from the sea.

However this place has gotten too popular as there seems to always be a giant line outside now. The one espresso machine is not enough to keep up with demand and the line moves slowly. Bring a book or your iPhone!

Another minor letdown is the roasted whole beans. I bought a couple different bags and neither have the flavors I'd expect for $10 for  8oz.

Despite the wait it's still worth it. The baristas still friendly and concentrate on you. And still craft a delicious drink.
author: Patrick S.

description:
This place is pretty bomb!

Introduced by a friend who strongly recommended the Snowy Plover drink, decided to give it a try on a Saturday afternoon. Andytown is located in the quiet sunset neighborhood and you will almost miss it if you simply drive by since it's kind of in the middle of nowhere. [Ahem good luck finding street parking] greeted by energetic and friendly staff, went ahead and order the Snowy Plover and see how it's like.

[Snowy Plover]: A
Honestly if you only look at the three main ingredients of this drink - coffee, soda water and whip cream, you would have never imagined how good these three things go together. YES it was so good. First of all, you can't treat this as a "coffee" - think about going to get a boba tea or smoothies type of dessert drink instead. Then, with coffee's bitterness, it was perfectly neutralized and became a dessert type of drink by the sweet soda water - with a feeling/texture of drinking coke or sprite. But since coffee and soda water are both considered pretty strong for your mouth and throat - the whip cream completely balance the feeling out and enhanced the overall drinking experience. After I stirred the drink, the three ingredients completely blended together well, and enter my throat smoothly with a bitter sweet flavor.

Strongly recommending the Snowy Plover! I'm sure they make regular coffee stuff e.g. Latte or Cappuccino above average as well, but man I don't know if I can ever get away with the snowy plover whenever I go there again!
author: Simon C.

description: Great friendly staff. They roast their own coffee. latte art is on point. The baking is out of this world good. I can't say enough about this shop but it is definitely my favorite stop in San Francisco.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Finally got to try out Andytown Coffee Roasters - it's a small coffee shop in the Outer Sunset, SF. It's famous for their Snowy Plover Coffee Drink - I think it's espresso, Pellegrino, and homemade whipped cream. 

Scones are freshly made and the cheddar scallion scone $3.75 I tried was warm & pretty tasty for a scone.

I saw Ritchie from Hapa Ramen there & SF Firefighters in line outside. Some seating inside & out. One unisex bathroom in the back. 

Hrs:
Closed Mondays
Tues-Fri 7am-3pm
Sat & Sun 8am-3pm

PS: if you happen to be there around 3pm when it's closed you might score leftover food that owner leaves out for freeloaders, oh yeah!
author: Ann L.

description:
The Snowy Plover.  
The baked goods.
The aesthetic.
These are the reasons why you should come here.  

The Snowy Plover is a fabulous concoction of espresso & pellegrino on ice, topped w house made whipped cream.  It's fantastic.  I capitalize the Snowy Plover on purpose, because I believe its greatness warrants a capitalized name.

Their baked goods are baked in house.  Do the strawberry corn muffin.  I devoured it.  Warm, right out of the oven...absolutely delicious.  And gluten free!

It's very small, yes.  But it's a great space.  Fabulous light.  Clean aesthetic.  Flowers on the tables.  The light color scheme adds to the soothing & welcoming vibe.  It's minimalist, but warm at the same time.

Love.
Like Marla Bakery, Andytown's an extraordinary addition to the sunset.

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Snowy Plover.... God damnit. It was effing heavenly delicious! I haven't had something like this one in South Korea when I was very young. I will definitely come back for this when I have a chance to visit San Francisco because this is the best coffee shop I have ever been to.

Everything is wonderfully great!
author: John K.

description: Omg. The muffin is supper good here!! Perfect choice if you visit the golden gate park
author: Peizhi Z.

description: Amazing coffee!!! The cappucino blew my mind! Chocolate chip cookie was also amazing. Great service, nice outside seating area... truly a gem!
author: Paloma M.

description:
My new favorite coffee place in San Francisco, and this is saying a lot.

I mean, I make the drive out here - to the vastness of the Outer Sunset on Lawton street - just for Andytown.

With staff that friendly, a roast so smooth, and a drink as uniquely addicting as the snowy plover, really - how could I go anywhere else?

Hats off to @gmlucci who makes the most incredible peaches and sweet goat cheese corn muffins, sausage rolls, jalapeno cheese corn muffins, berry scones, strawberry cornbread muffins and MORE (yes, cornmeal is a theme). I come in for a fast coffee and end up staying to soak in the experience of a delicious, heart warming snack in the mellow Outer Sunset. 

I'm secretly glad that Andytown is in as an obscure spot as Lawton street, but I am certain that this amazing storefront will be revealed soon. 

Another plus, on top of everything else?
*They take credit card.
*Parking is not impossible at all.
*It's always a fast line :)
author: Colleen M.

description: Good iced mocha. Great vibe in the place. Would recommend!!
author: Serenity D.

description:
Okay so im in LOVE with their snowy plover. Andytown was one of the roasters that had a stand at the SF Coffee Fest, and i couldn't get enough of that drink. I need one right now just thinking about it. 

PS, their whip cream tastes amazing.
author: Alyssa F.

description: BEST COFFEE IN SF the sweet latte is to dir for. Atmosphere is pleasant and community oriented, plus nice view from the beach while you drink sf's best coffee
author: Lucia B.

description:
have i played my favorite coffee shop card already? okay i take it back then and wholeheartedly offer it to andytown. im on my knees beggin please someone set up a portal so i can zip back and forth from nj to here on any sad lonesome whim. 

so if theres something i learned about myself during this trip is that i am absolute trash when it comes to sf transit. at 8am i took the n train, happy go lucky with the prospect of seeing the beach first thing in the morning, only to suddenly be surrounded by all the techies in caltrain waiting to commute into soma. i felt so stupid. but i had to persevere. andytown was calling me.

apart from that lil flib i made it to andytown where a number of people were seated, some donning the store's beanies, others bopping their heads to the early morning screamo tunes of a girl ive never heard of before. the first thing i noticed was how nicely lit the small shop was, with its big windows and light fixtures hanging from the ceiling. it's an adorable store, that all the pictures capture rightly.

and then the second thing i noticed was just how enthusiastic and friendly the barista at the register was. that, and what the heck is he pouring an immaculate rosetta while taking someone's order? what is going on here??

i order a cortado (to which he replies: all right, one gibraltar, would that be all? thats gonna stick with me haha) and its got a beautiful little tulip, just a perfect few ounces of creamy crema goodness.

and then that's when i notice that the door is freakin out the DOOR around the corner of the street. and it stays like that for probably twenty minutes. i wanted to ask for some water at the counter but i felt like i was disrupting the work groove they had going on.

everyone behind the counter was bustling about dutily grabbing this cup then that board then restocking and wow it was such beautiful cohesion amongst everyone. they even took the time to chat with locals, and a stranger like me. and the guy at the register again--he probably sold fifteen strawberry muffins in the span of five minutes. i have never seen someone pull customer service so effortlessly as they do a ristretto. that was incredible.

i also got their cheddar scallion scone once the craziness died down (which picked right back up, unsurprisingly by that point) and whew that was good. i had to try one of their irish soda goods and i'm glad i allotted my breakfast funds to that instead of some sweet toast.

i heard someone mention "stickers" so i thought decals were for sale. no--theyre free. WHY do they keep giving me reasons to love em like dam. those stickers are so freakin adorable. made my entire trip.

my final word: deal with the hellish n train delays and give this place a shot. just make sure to head away from caltrain and towards ocean beach, and get there early to beat the lines.

thank you so much andytown. hugs n kisses
author: Angie K.

description:
This is a cute little coffee place. There was a bit of a line here but, you know, lines usually mean there's something worth the wait at the end of it. There was not a lot of seating inside, but there were a couple places to sit outside. 

So this review is just for the snowy plover, seeing as that's the only item we tried. Basically, it's sparkling water with a shot of espresso with a big scoop of THE BEST CREAM EVER (no, seriously, if they sold just the cream, I would just eat that). I personally really liked the drink; it was more unique than your usual coffee drink. My friends thought it was ok but we all agreed that the cream was amazing. 

Also, this place is walking distance (8 min walk) from Outerlands. So if you wanted to try there, you can walk over here after and kill two birds with one stone.
author: Eunice L.

description: Just had my first snowy plover - it was a religious experience. So so good! Also had a scallion scone, and it was so buttery and delicious. Super friendly staff and clean shop. Definately gonna come here more often!
author: Bethy B.

description:
I've been here a 5-6 of times and thoroughly enjoyed their signature snowy plover and their corn muffins. Today was the day that I finally tried their soda bread and am so propelled to write this review.
