That soda bread that runs out before 11a, with raw cheddar and bacon. It's to die for. That balance in the mild cheddar with the saltiness and slightly oily bacon was insane. I didn't have words beside mmhmmm, in every bite. and of course the nodding of my head. lol You might think I'm blowing this out of the portion, but it was good!! Don't want to forget about their strawberry corn muffin which was magnificent as well. I didn't know that corn muffin can taste so strawberry-ey. 


I highly recommend trying their pastry.   We arrived around 9:30 and waited 35 mins to order and 10mins to get our food. With the space and their food, i understand but it just sucks to have to wait so long. The reason for 4 stars is the wait and i think their regular coffee is okay.
author: Hei Ming C.

description:
very friendly staff here unlike many of the other hipster coffee places. they actually smile and have upbeat personalities. I am used to the pretentious attitudes that I was taken back and fell in love with this place at first hello. 

of course I tried the Snowy Plover. if you're into drinking Pellegrino then you will like this. I don't like sparkling water much but I got used to drinking this toward the end. also has two shot of espresso, brown sugar syrup, and home made whipped cream. mixed it well and it somehow works. 

the fresh ginger tea was good! I have searched high and low for a decent ginger tea and they have a good one here. mildly sweet and serves about 2 cup from tea pot. 

The cacao sea salt cookie was pretty good too. Not too sweet which is how I like it.

the soda bread was big and thick and I added cheese and bacon. ended up eating the bacon and cheese separately because it was awkward eating them all together. 

Can't wait to try their other items on the menu. parking was decent on a weekday around 3pm.
author: Jules L.

description: Love love this little gem in the neighborhood!!  Tried snowy plover once and I'm hooked!  Quaint little place for coffee, get together, do your homework, or check the weather in Palau for next month. You gotta tried this unique blend of drink!!!  Espresso + club soda + homemade whipped cream!!  In line as I write and drooling!
author: Lisa V.

description:
Love ice coffee? Try Snowy Plover!
Like whipped cream? Gotta order Snowy Plover!!
Want something different and special? It's Snowy Plover!!!
Here's the way to drink it. 
Don't stir at beginning. 
Sip it, taste the coffee. 
Use a spoon, scope up the cream with coffee flavor. Creamy, soft, dreamy whipped cream is so tasty. 
Sip it, scope it back and forth till half way...
Then stir it up, it's whole new different thing. 
Mmmmmmmm.... My fav!!!
author: JustinE Y.

description:
Andytown Coffee Roasters is THE WHOLE PACKAGE.  Delicious coffee, scrumptious baked goodies, cheerful ambiance, feel-good music, cute cactuses--what more can you ask for? The only downside (for me) is that it's a 30 minute bike ride away from my apartment. Although, that hasn't stopped me from making the trip out here multiple times in just the past month... 

Tip #1: Both bike and car parking nearby. There's not much seating room inside the coffee shop though, so most people take their food and drinks to go. There are a few indoor and outdoor tables, but keep in mind that it's Outer Sunset, so there's a perpetual chill in the air. *brrrr*

Tip #2: Baked pastries are fantastic! They have gluten free goodies here as well. 

Tip #3: If you're biking from Mission area, take The Wiggle to avoid the hills. The Wiggle is a bike route--Google Maps will automatically route you through it. 

Overall: In a city awash with high-quality coffee shops, it takes a lot to stand out. Andytown Coffee Roasters does so, despite being off the beaten path, and has become one of my favorite coffee shops in the city.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Came by for coffee the other day and it was fantastic! The mocha came out not too sweet and the homemade whip cream is to die for! Try it!

Ordered a Peach muffin and it was phenomenal as Yelpers raved about!

The coffee shop is slightly out of place for being in the Sunset district!

$8.5 for a coffee and pastry! Credit cards accepted via Square!
author: Derek S.

description: Stopped in here after a swim for some morning coffee and pastries. It was raining outside so this was the perfect spot to warm up and get cozy with the wet weather. There was a sizeable line for 10AM, but it moved pretty quickly. They have a nice small selection of home made muffins, scones and soda bread that go great with their tea and coffee. The berry corn muffin may actually be better than Arizmendi's. Food and drinks are served on fun wooden planks. I like how they serve the drinks in unique pottery rather than the typical ceramics at most cafes. Parking in the area is pretty easy. Seating is limited.
author: Alice H.

description:
During a recent Kickstarter campaign, Andytown Coffee Roasters raised $21,600 against a $15,000 goal. I was one of the 282 Backers with a modest $30 contribution. At some future date, that gets me a pan of soda bread, an 8 ounce bag of coffee beans and a drink pog. 

I think Lauren and Michael were behind the counter yesterday when I stopped in. I was there to anonymously take a look at my "investment" and enjoy a rich cup of coffee and what turned out to be an amazing fresh baked gluten-free berry muffin. There as also a warm scone (with a complicated pedigree) right out of the oven that I should have purchased. 

Andytown Coffee Roasters threw off a nice neighborhood vibe, including a communal table (with an attractive shape and wood choice), an nice friendly busy buzz, and free dog treats. They also have four small tables down one side of this somewhat narrow shop, each with their own power outlet so people can get a little work done. 

Let's say that crowd funding is a neat thing and Andytown Coffee Roasters is satisfying success story. I'm sure I'll be back, if only to try more of their tasty backed goods and eventually pick up my soda bread. And yes, the coffee (I also bought beans) is also excellent.
author: Eric B.

description:
Wonderul addition to our block and community! Lauren and Michael are the nicest small business owners you'd ever meet. the space is gorgeously hand assembled by michael and friends. the works of foamy milk art are handcrafted by Lauren and team. and you cannot cannot leave without tasting the housemade pastries. whether it's the cherry chocolate scone or the legendary irish sausage rolls, they are simply fantastic! and recently added outdoor seating (in the foggy western side of SF no less) makes this corner spot not only a destination spot but a lingering hangout refuge too.
an onsite commercial coffee roasting machine ensures the freshest and most carefully handcrafted artisan coffee in the neighborhood.
keep up the great work Lauren and Michael and much success to you at AndyTown.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Andytown is literally 2 blocks away from me and it's also really close to my old elementary school- FSKey. I used to cut class during recess and climb up the fence to run to Kara's corner cup (before it was Andytown Roasters) and get a cream cheese and jam bagel when I was 9 or 10... (I'm 24 now) so this corner spot on Lawton and 43rd spot held a lot of memories for me. 

I knew Kara's was gonna close one day but I'm glad it became something I could love. So now instead of Kara's I come to Andytown. I usually get their lattes because they make it pretty well. It's a double shot latte so there's more coffee taste than regular lattes. It's smooth and aromatic, tasting more like coffee than cream/milk. Most places have it the other way around. Their baked goods like their scones are also on point and their bread+butter are great pairings with the coffee. 

Also, their snowy plover is bomb but its pretty big and filling. Though I actually see it more as a coffee type of dessert than coffee-coffee (maybe because 1/2 of it is whipped cream) ya feel? I get it when I'm in the mood for something a little more filling and sweet. And did I mention they make it with sparkling water? Fancyyyy

Cons: I don't like their regular black coffee. Tasted too acidic for me. I felt that it just kinda overtook all the aromatic fragrance of the coffee bean itself.  But this is a personal preference.
author: Janet K.

description:
I love coffee, especially artisan local roasteries.  Heard a lot of good things about Andytown and I came today on my day off. It's a cute corner shop and hidden gem for us local SF natives. No crazy long line like Philz (which is overrated) and a calm vibe to relax with awesome coffee.

The staff is very friendly and they have a simple selection of corn muffins & scones. I tried the famous Snowy Plover - OMG! It's more fabulous than I had imagined :) I will return...take me to Andytown!
author: Kaila Y.

description:
Dreaming of a mocha right now....

5 mins later
Dreaming of a corn muffin with a jam pocket.

10 mins later
Dreaming of a cheddar scallion scone.

15 mins later
Lets go. LOL

Seriously anything you get here is top notch and so so good. Coffee is bold and flavorful. Pastries are well made and delicious.
author: Christine G.

description: Snowy Plover? Really? My partner and I each took a sip and tossed it in the trash. Not sure what all the hype is because it tasted pretty damn awful. Friendly staff though and service was fast. I'm sure their regular coffee is just fine.
author: Shawn I.

description: Love this place. Coffee is always good and strong, served with care and a smile. Snowy plover is a must on hot days and their pastries aren't bad either. I'm sure everyone has said this but the place is tiny and the line is always out the door. I wish it were bigger so I could work there more often.
author: Virg A.

description:
I LOVE Andytowns! 

My first visit there was Saturday. My friend and I ordered 2 snowy plovers, a strawberry corn meal muffin and a cheesy scone. My friend loved the scone so much she commented that it was better than Arizmendi's. 
Everything was delicious! The snowy plover consists of ice, brown sugar syrup, sparkling water, a shot of fresh espresso and their thick homemade whipped cream. This is now my go to drink of choice ;)
After my friend and I finished drinking our snowy plovers we were seriously debating getting in line again to get another (yes it was that good! But yea the line.) So good that it's Sunday and I'm drinking my snowy plover writing this review!!!
author: Liz N.

description:
One of the things that was missing from the Outer Sunset was a great, neighborhood coffee bar. Sure, there's Trouble Coffee, but who wants to deal with rude baristas who scoff at your lower espresso IQ. Andytown fills this void and I could not be happier at how this grassroots project has turned out. 

The friendly staff has been grateful for the support that they have received in putting together this community startup and this has translated into quality coffee, amazing housemade pastries, and ties to local ceramics (see the dinosaur mugs). The signature drink here is the snowy plover. Concocted from a shot of espresso, sparkling water, simple syrup, and homemade whipped cream, this refreshing beverage is sure to cool you on the hottest of Indian summer days. I'm a little bit surprised by how good it is given the industry standard to frown upon mixing espresso with any iced beverage. 
Make sure to also grab a fresh cheddar scallion scone to go with the coffee!
author: Bailey Z.

description:
So good!!! Got here at 7:55am on a Sat, didn't wait long at all. The service was fantastic, Caroline took our order and was incredibly friendly. The rest of the crew was very warm as well. 

Got 4 different types of drinks between our group, everyone was pleased. Their espresso is . The baked goods were also delicious. We will 100000% be back.
author: Gina H.

description:
My favorite coffee place in the city. I love starting my day Saturday or Sunday mornings by stopping by here for a coffee or cappucino and then walking over to Devil's Teeth Baking Co. for a breakfast sandwich. 

Their espresso drinks are some of the best in the city. They do a killer almond latte, almond mocha, and cappucino. Their most well known drink is the Snowy Plover, which is a sweetened double shot of espresso over pellegrino water, topped off with a large helping of house-made whipped cream. The whipped cream is AMAZING. It's thick, creamy, and the perfect sweetness to accompany the espresso. The Snowy Plover can be pretty heavy by itself, so I often like to get the 'Snowless' version without the whipped cream -- a tasty alternative to a normal cold brew or iced coffee. 

The baked goods at Andytown are also fantastic. The corn muffins, scones, and cookies are all delicious. The soda bread is good too, but a bit plain for my tastes. 

Also, the staff is super nice and friendly, much more so than the nearby Trouble Coffee, whose employees don't really seem like they enjoy working there at all. 

Outer Sunset is a bit out of the way of most things in the city, but Andytown is definitely worth the trip.
author: Eric W.

description:
A great coffee shop in the Outer Sunset! My friend and I came here today and we ordered almond milk lattes, a blueberry corn muffin, and a soda current scone. The lattes were great - the perfect espresso to milk ratio. The soda current scone was also really good, but the blueberry corn muffin shined through. I think their use of corn in the pastries is what makes them so good. If you come here, definitely get a pastry. The muffins...are to die for. Also they are known for their snowy plover (espresso, soda water, & whipped cream); it sounds really weird but it's actually really good! I recommend this for first timers, it's an Andytown signature. 

The place is pretty small, and it gets super crowded all the time. It's more of a pick up and go type of place, although if you are lucky and wait around you can sit at the little communal table or one of the few tables against the wall. The place has a really beachy hip vibe mixed with the trendy San Francisco coffee shop vibe without being snooty and pretentious as a lot of other places. The people are always nice, and you never are intimidated to ask for help or for any information on the coffee or just talk to them about anything.

Overall, Andytown has definitely topped my list of best coffee places the City has to offer.
author: Steph V.

description: Great coffee but the staff is SLOW.  The line can be short and the wait is still absurd.  They need a little hustle in this joint or I'll have to stop going.
author: Michael S.

description:
Staff is awesome.  Always a long line but worth the wait.  A snowy plover??? What the heck is that.  JUST TRY IT! IT'S AWESOME!! and very addicting. 
I do wish the had gluten-free choices for snacks but hey the snowy plover is epic...
author: Mia B.

description: The iced latte is smooth and is nice and strong. Not bitter strong, but the perfect roast of espresso. Ambiance is everything, love it.
author: Ally T.

description:
Welcome to the neighborhood Andytown! Warm, welcoming space with a communal table in the front that encourages conversations between neighbors. I was one of the first in line for its opening party and it did not disappoint. 

I chose the Snowy Plover even though the coffee and espresso were free because who could resist a drink named after a cute ocean beach bird? A "coffee cream soda" - espresso, simple syrup, freshly made cream and sparkling water - it was a hit among many new customers.

A fresh currant scone topped off a delicious morning. 

Can't wait to visit again :)
author: Dyanna Q.

description:
Recommend: snowy plover, sweetened latte

Yass this place satisfies my inner coffee snob. Coffee roasted and pastries freshly baked. It's  a bit small but that's ok with me.
author: Hanna K.

description:
The snowy plover (pellegrino, espresso, whip cream) is fantastic and refreshing. Perfect for a pick me up on warm day and surprisingly a thirst-quencher. Darling ambiance and decor that is bright and happy on this San Francisco winter day. Love the hot fresh ginger tea- great zing and perfect for a stuffy nose and cold! Service was outstanding. This place is a win in my book. 

The butternut squash, thyme, onion and goat cheese scone was savory and delicious. Must try. Split one with a friend!
author: Aleyna S.

description:
This cafe reminds me of some pop-up shop in New York. I love finding new cafes in my neighborhood. They always have something different, and that snowy plover drink is definitely a first for me ... preeetttyy delicious. 
I'm not some coffee connoisseur, but I've had my fair share of different types of caffeinated goodness and I've never had anything like that. The best part about it is that homemade whipped cream...mmmmmm... If someone gave me a tub of that, I would get a spoon, sit on my fatass, put on Netflix, and shamelessly eat it on a Saturday night. 

4.5 stars for the drink. Extra half star for the barista not getting offended with that stripper joke I made and carrying it on.. Kudos, sense of humor is always appreciated. :)
author: Jessie D.

description: Love the Snowy Plover & Raspberry Corn Muffin ! A must have every time I visit in town. The weight time line to order is about 15-20 min. Dog friendly outdoor place with treats.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Sunday, 2:00 PM.

Quickie:
+ Food quality
+ Hygiene
+ Customer service
+ Turnaround
+ Chill vibe
+ Menu variety
* Layout

And then...?
Andytown Coffee Roasters makes good drinks and even better pastries. Y'all got it goin' on!

**********
Stuffed my face in:

1. Soda farl with jam and cheddar
     + House-made jam, was the appropriate sweetness level.
     + Generous portions of raw cheddar.
     + Farl was fluffy and had firm edges.
author: Chuck N.

description: I hate everything about this place - the expensive but gross coffee, the entitled yuppie crowd, the bland, cookie-cutter gentrifying coffee shop aesthetics, and of course, the gentrification itself. Hope it burns down.
author: Ian G.

description:
Just blocks away from the Pacific Ocean, this cafe is such a gorgeous addition to the neighborhood.

The snowy plower is worth the hype- tonic espresso with homemade whipped cream. 
The baked goods are pretty tasty too; we had the cheddar jalapeño muffin, apple pear muffin and strawberry chocolate scone were yummy. 
Will definitely be back if I'm in the hood. Just be prepared to stand in line for at least 20 mins on the weekend.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
*Supposedly the snowy plover drink ($4) is one of their best seller, however I didn't know what it was until I got home and read Yelp reviews :( so I regret for not getting it.... The snowy plover is an espresso drink mixed with Italian soda and topped with homemade whipped cream, sounds very intriguing!

*The lineup can be a pain but it moves very quickly, also if you are in SF and there is no line up at a shop, you know that place ain't popular by locals ;).

-Lyons Tea Au Lait - $3.25: 
Essentially a tea latte, and if I remember correctly it was black tea! The tea wasn't too strong and there was some smoothness to it? I hope that make sense, but I enjoyed it and I appreciate how the barista held back on the syrup too.

-Soda Black Currant Scone - $4.00: 
Initially I was afraid that the soda scone would be dry, however it was still warm and moist inside. The blackcurrant tasted like concentrated blackberry and it wasn't too overpowering either.
author: Anh T.

description:
This place is...freakin awesome and my new favorite coffee spot!

The snowy plover combines everything I love - fizzy h2o, espresso and fresh whipped cream. Truly, heaven in a cup :).

This coffee spot is super cute and the staff is very friendly. I found a seat towards the back and Michael (I think is the owner) asked me, "how's the P-Lover"...I told him it was my first time having it and it was awesome.

More P-Lover's to come my way very soon ;).
author: Denise K.

description: If you want to roll into the sunset and charge as much as you do--That's fine but have a proper self service station for people putting their coffee together. No milk and sugar for me to complete my order after five minutes of waiting for a simple ice coffee.... and to flash a tip screen is tasteless in my opinion. You're in the sunset remind you, be a bit more professional.
author: Shawn W.

description:
Andytown is one of my new favorite coffee shops in the city! As a connoisseur of the cappuccino, theirs is solid! I think it might be in my top ten. 

In addition to the great espresso, their baked goods are delicious! I had a blackberry pear cornbread muffin and it was was really tasty. It's really nice that they are made on site.

They take great care in the presentation of their coffee and the shop itself. It's got great atmosphere and the staff is really friendly!
author: Cindy L.

description: Busy hipster cafe that serves a good cup of jo.
author: Mai T.

description: Located in the avenues, this place is a bit tucked away in a street corner. Look for the anarchy symbol "A". Ordered the snowy plow, cheese & scallion scone, blueberry corn muffin, and cherry corn muffin with sweet goat cheese filling. The homemade whip cream in the snowy plow is as advertised: delectable. Surprisingly tasty and refreshing for a fizzy espresso iced drink. Pastries were all on point: sweet, crispy crust and moist inside. Lastly, their staff was friendly and enthusiastic. Seems like a fun place to hang out. I'll be back here this weekend!
author: Barnaby W.

description:
I LOVE this place! The staff is friendly, the drinks are on point, and the pastries and bread are super tasty. 

My favorite drinks are the almond milk latte, which somehow tastes creamy, and the snowy plover, which is like a coffee root beer float. 

Their savory offerings are my favorite. If they have it, I highly recommend the cheddar and scallion scone, and the raw cheddar and bacon on either of the bread choices. Soooooo good!

It's a really light, airy, fresh feeling place with a beautiful wood table in the front for shared seating and 3 or 4 small tables and stools along one wall inside. There is also some outside seating with surprisingly sturdy wooden folding chairs outside. For as small as the space is I think they've worked in a decent amount of seating. 

Excellent coffee shop with everything you could want: good coffee, tasty food, friendly staff, and beautiful decor. Love, love, love it!
author: Niku B.

description:
Super excited about this new location!!! Per the usual, amazing staff and amazing coffee. Congrats on the second location!!!
It's a block away from the beach, which means I can order my Snowy Plover (best drink in the entire universe) and hang out at the beach on those nice San Francisco dayzzz.
author: J C.

description:
I usually don't drink coffee at all, but Andytown has gotten me hooked on their famous snowy plover which is a mix of expresso, italian soda and whipped cream - an odd combination that surprisingly works extremely well.  It is like a coffee-flavored Italian soda.  

Also, go early for their coveted cornbread which are sweet and sell out quickly.
author: Hieu H.

description:
Super nice staff and great coffee! 

They were on point with talking about there offerings, managing the line and proving fast service. 

Make sure to try their muffins as well!
author: Will M.

description: The customer service I received was absolutely outstanding! After waiting maybe ten minutes in a line that went out the door of the tiny establishment, I eagerly asked several questions of the barista who was primarily taking orders. I had never visited this roasters and wondered about which beans she recommended for the taste and mouthfeel that I prefer. Although there was a line behind me, she gave me undivided attention as though I was the only customer while another barista came up from behind her and seamlessly assisted with helping the other people in line. The barista assisting me demonstrated thorough knowledge of coffee and accurately described each of the beans that they had on the shelf. She had a passion and interest in the coffee experience and in assisting me in having a wonderful visit. I purchased the Ethiopia Natural Misty Valley at $12.50 for 8 ounces. If only I lived in the city I would be a committed customer. I would give the highest recommendation of this place to anyone who loves coffee and I will return if I am back in the city. The barista who helped me is certainly an asset to Andytown. Thank you for giving me such a great experience.
author: Anita M.

description: Wish this spot wasn't quite so deep into the city and was more accessible. The spot is REALLY SMALL...don't expect to snag a seat inside. The outdoor seating is also pretty limited, but done really nicely. On a nice day, the outdoor seating proves to be really pleasant. They are small, fast, clean, and efficient. Known for their snowy plover...don't be weirded out by the pellegrino part. It's FANTASTIC. Only problem for me is that they tend to be a little heavy on the cream, but it's nice that it's whipped cream so you can always scoop some out for taste.
author: Annie S.

description:
Amazing coffee and scrumptious baked treats served out of a super cute storefront with little nooks for 1 or 2 people along the inside wall, a cozy seating area up front, and some seats outside that would be super cozy if and when it's not bone-chillingly cold outside. 

Whether it's the coffee, baked goods, or service, this place rises far and above a typical neighborhood coffeehouse, so much so that it's worth the trek out here if you're not from the immediate area.
author: Vincent L.

description: My favorite place in the sunset delicious bake goods amazing coffee good music and awesome ambiance truly a gem in the sunset!
author: amy h.

description: Best mocha I've ever had! It's not too sweet and the flavour's just amazing. Don't skip on the whip. Pair it with a blueberry muffin and it's seriously the best breakfast/brunch ever.
author: Beckie E.

description:
Update: after visiting a few other small "boutique" coffee shops, I see that the price is normal for a cappuccino but the size still seems way smaller than a 12 oz.

 The cappuccino tasted pretty average, no complaints. At first I thought I was being handed a sample but then I realized that was my drink. It's pretty tiny for the Starbucks price. Should have just went to a chain if I was going to pay for a sample
author: Nick L.

description:
Andytown happens to be this corner coffee spot which mercifully provides excellent artisan coffee to those of us living out in the Outer Sunset.

At this point, I would go into some description about their coffee and/or espresso drinks, either that or some ramblings on how I'm loving the fact they got some of their initial funding through Kickstarter.  But the thing that really caught my attention was a drink called
The Snowy Plover.

For those of you who are familiar with what an egg cream is, it's kinda like a coffee version of that.

For those who don't know what an egg cream is, allow me to explain:
It's a fountain drink (which I usually associated with NYC) that consist of thick chocolate syrup, seltzer water, and milk.  Those ingredients are blended together (to which there is some debate on whether the chocolate or the seltzer goes on the bottom) to create a rather refreshing not so sweet chocolaty drink.

For those of you familiar with Yoo-hoo, it reminds of the chocolate one.

For those of you who don't know what a Yoo-hoo is:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoo-hoo
(I'm tired of writing).

Where was I going with this review?
Oh right, the coffee . . . 

The coffee has a clean bright finish and is super smooth.  The cappuccino also exhibits that lighter taste and is a real nice change from the ones that have a little more bite to them. 
And try the Snowy Plover - it's quite invigorating.
author: Dan B.

description:
Two words: Snowy Plover

Cute, straight out of Pinterest, coffee shop in Sunset! Decor is amazing, menu is simple, and coffee is on point. The baristas here are all so cheerful and friendly :) It has such a fun vibe. I came here to celebrate their 1st birthday! I got to try their famous Snowy Plover! I wanted to get a latte but I could get a latte anywhere, the snowy plover though is unique to this place. 

The snowy plover consists of Pellegrino sparkling water, espresso (already sweetened with brown sugar), and homemade whipped cream. The simplicity of this drink shouldn't fool you because it's wonderful and refreshing. It's basically a fizzy coffee drink. I'm not a fan of cream but their whipped cream was delicious...almost like ice cream. So glad I got this drink but I was a little bummed that I missed out on the latte art (because it looks so cool). 

The cafe is small with only 3 small tables that can sit 2 and one big table in the front of shop that can sit 5-7 people. They have outdoor seating as well that can sit parties of 2. It's located on a street corner with easy street parking. Highly recommended if you're in the area :)
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I love this place. I live a few blocks down and I don't know why I don't come here more often. (Actually, yes I do - it's because I'd overdose on their berry corn muffins!)

I've come here twice and am very satisfied with both experiences. I've ordered the same thing both times. I'll switch it up next time! I promise...maybe. 

The service is great and friendly. Those corn muffins, as I hinted, are delightful! The first time I went there was strawberry in them - it's like taking a bite of sunshine, and today they had blueberry. Still very tasty and they're not dry like other corn muffins I've had and half of the muffin goes a long way. Then of course, the wheaten soda bread with aged cheddar and bacon brings a tear of joy to my eye after the first bite. The best thing about it is that it's a big portion as well, so you can save the other half for lunch or throw it in the toaster oven the next morning and throw a fried egg on top. Yeah I said it! 

Definitely try this place out if you're nearby or heading to the beach on a sunny (or foggy) morning!
author: Jess G.

description:
I found the warm smile,fast service,and friendly demeanor of Caring Carolyn to be five star excellent.I came in with a group of friends and Caring Carolyn did not make use feel rushed,she had a very upbeat personality,she delivered our order quickly and friendly,as well as doing the exact same thing with each customer after use as far as we could see.She is a rare one this Caring Carolyn and Andytown should consider themselves lucky to have her.
Well done Caring Carolyn,well done.
Freddy
author: Fred S.

description: First time trying the Snowy Plover, I love sparking water and sparking drinks so this sparking caffeinated drink was right up my alley. Next time, I will ask for more sugar or more syrup but the fluffy house made cream was a nice addition to the drink. From pictures, the cream looked like ice cream and I think ice cream would have made a really nice addition to this drink! It would have really been a coffee float! I will come back again to try the lattes and pastries! As I was ordering I've noticed that a lot of other customers ordered the lattes, I like sweeter drinks so I will have to give them a try next time. Parking was not bad either! Always a nice plus! ;)
author: Jennifer H.

description: The snowy plover has opened up our eyes to all that can be done with coffee. Way to think out of the box and deliver a truly unique and delicious drink.
author: Lindsey W.

description:
I had been meaning to try Andytown for a while, and finally got the chance to on Sunday afternoon, and it did not disappoint!

I love their pastries-the blueberry muffin was not too sweet and was just perfect, and the asparagus and goat cheese scone was great to have as a heartier option (a smidge spicy, but nothing unmanageable). 

I got an almond milk cappachino and it was smooth and wonderful. My friend got a mocha and it was a bit bitter from the dark chocolate (which I was super into so I thought it was great, though I think she would have preferred a bit sweeter). The staff was friendly and worked quickly.

Warning: we went right after the church service got out across the street, so it was very busy. But the service was still great and the line went quickly!
author: Marilyn M.

description:
This place has some of the best coffee I've ever tasted. They also have teas and hot cocoas. I've had their coffee, mocha, hot chocolate, and famous snowy plover. The mocha, hot chocolate, and snowy plower all come with whipped cream, which I think is delicious. It is thick creamy and home made. I highly recommend all of their coffee drinks. I have also tried the snowy plover, which wasn't my favorite. Many people seem to come in and ask for it. It is espresso with sparkling water and whipped cream on top. For me, the sparkling water is just a little strange, but other people seem to love it and come here just for that drink!

This place also has delicious baked goods. Their cookies crumble when you eat them and are super sweet, but not overly so. Their scones are pretty good, but a little dry. But my favorite is the soda bread, which comes with cheddar cheese or jam (also their oven closes at 3pm, so be sure to get there before that!)

The service here is friendly and attentive. They always strike up conversation and make you feel welcome. The baristas are talkative and take the time to talk to you and recommend drinks if you want. Also, shoutout to the barista that gave me a free coffee refill when they were about to close!!

I also find this spot suitable to get a little bit of work done. There is wifi and one large table you can share with others where you can sprawl out and get stuff done. There are other smaller tables inside and a bunch outside as well. This cafe has a nice vibe with good music and the sound level is fine for reading or whatever you need to do!

Side note, this is one cafe in sf that actually has street parking! I don't have to struggle to parallel park or spend half an hour finding a spot!
author: Julie L.

description:
Every single time I'm in the Bay Area, I trek to the Outer Sunset to make the trip to A-town. Whipped cream is probably my favorite food (judge away, I don't care), so the snowy plover is my dream drink. You may not think that fizzy coffee sounds like it would be good. Just trust the folks here and try a snowy plover. You'll be thanking yourself for days. The espresso is so smooth, it's just the right amount of sweet, and it's refreshing while still feeling indulgent with that giant glob of homemade whip on top. 

The decor in here is stunning- there's a huge wooden table towards the front of the shop that gets amazing light on a nice day. That said, I prefer to take my snowy plover to Ocean Beach or to one of the three or four tables outside to enjoy some nice weather. I haven't yet tried their baked goods, but people seem to clamor over the scones and cookies, so I'd assume they're pretty solid. 

Bottom line: if you want great quality coffee done in a unique way in a beautifully designed shop, Andytown is definitely worth the ride on the N.
author: Alex G.

description: I'm absolutely in love with this coffee place. It's crowded every single time because the coffee is that good! I ordered the snowy plover and boy it was great. I love trying different coffee drinks that aren't common in typical coffee shops or Starbucks etc. The snowy plover is that unique drink you can't order anywhere. I don't understand why the best places are usually not as spacious and it took my friend and I awhile to even get a table to stand/put our drinks down and chit chat. People love hanging out at this coffee shop so it's understandable. I regret not ordering the cheddar scone because I heard it's super delicious but something I'm looking forward to get next time. And to the baristas at this place, you guys are awesome!! So friendly.
author: Anne F.

description:
Finally tired their famous snowy plover. Wasn't a fan. Somehow it tasted salty to me. The whipped cream was delicious but I think the pellegrino threw me off. I would've enjoyed it more without the carbonated water part. I guess when it comes to coffee, I like to stay traditional.

The space was cute and the baked goods smelled great! Next time I'll try one with a cup of old fashioned americano.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Andytown Coffee Roasters makes any coffee experience a unique one and everybody needs to make a stop here at least once. It's not like any other coffee shop I've been to. It's innovative while its product and decor are quirky and rustic. It's everything I love found conveniently in one location.

The ideal coffee experience:

COFFEE + PASTRY + TALKING WITH FRIENDS OR FAMILY OR COWORKERS

Even though Andytown Coffee Roasters has nailed both the coffee and pastry segment, they need to work on the third part. I enjoyed their product but they really need to have more seating inside though there is a little bit of seating.

My party ordered:

SNOWY PLOVER ($4): Interesting and innovative beverage consisting of layers of San Pellegrino carbonated water, coffee, and thicker/denser whipped cream; Mixed together it's very similar to a snowfall coffee with a very slight soda flavor; Though I was initially skeptical about the carbonated water (since I'm not a fan of a fizzy taste), I enjoyed it; The coffee and carbonated water melded together much better than I expected and the whipped cream gives the coffee that distinct flavor; Highly recommended for those who enjoy snowfall coffee with a hint of fizz

CAPPUCCINO ($3.50): Didn't really have this one but my bro said Andytown exceeded every aspect of what he likes in a coffee; Very smooth and light; Not bitter in the least bit; Nice coffee art; Excellent temperature control

STRAWBERRY AND CHOCOLATE SCONE ($3.75): Andytown nailed the texture; Slightly warm, toasted, and crumbly; Strawberry taste was infused throughout the entire scone

SERVICE: Really patient and answered our questions thoroughly; Came out with the coffee's and scone (pre-made but still warm) very quickly

DECOR: Place is cute, rustic, and narrow yet modern with shelves, coffee appliances, and "house" plants everywhere so my kind of place; The actual coffee bar stretches towards the back leaving only a few seats on the sides (probably built for parties of no more than two people), a communal table in the front with windows letting sunlight in, and a narrow walkway; Outside, there is plenty of seating though it's difficult to find at times

Will I return? Yes. But only if I'm in the area since I live quite far. Though I really enjoyed the innovation, beauty of the place, and my whole experience overall, it was a bit too troublesome for me to come here especially with little seating and horrific traffic. However, the coffee and the scones were so superb that it's definitely worth a revisit.
author: Jacquie H.

description: I loooove the snowy plovers! Fantastic!
author: Barbra P.

description: Ranked as one of the best coffee shops in SF and it lives up to it. Try to go during odd hours or right when they open on weekends to avoid the long lines
author: Eric R.

description: Very surprised to find a bustling cafe in residential neighborhood. The cafe is very small so it fills up.  Decor is modern trendy.  Coffee is good.
author: Byron L.

description:
We ordered the "Snowy Plover" at Andytown Coffee Roasters on a hot Saturday afternoon. The weather seemed perfect for an iced drink so we took a stroll over to this local hipster cafe. Unfortunately, we forgot to wear our plaid shirts and ride our fixie bikes but they were still very welcoming. 

The line went by quickly. $4 for a cup of espresso over ice, sweetener, S. Pellegrino, and whipped cream. Great concept but I wasn't impressed with the flavor. It was like a coffee cream soda - only good for 5 minutes but gets boring quick. 

3 stars for the convenient location and good customer service but I wouldn't return for the Snowy.
author: Winnie L.

description: Beautiful and trendy coffee restaurant. I call it a coffee restaurant because you can actually sit in there for hours, reading a book or sketching the beautiful bouquets of fresh flowers. I don't know which smelled better, the coffee or the flowers! :) Great design and craft coffee makers, add some caramel to the menu and you'll see me come back again and again.
author: Lara K.

description:
Such a great neighborhood coffee shop -- almost makes me wish I lived in Outer Sunset! 

However, thankfully, my company serves Andytown Coffee in our coffee bar everyday! My personal favorite is the infamous Snowy Plover with extra homemade cream. It's basically espresso, pellegrino and a brown sugar syrup topped with homemade cream, and it ends up tasting like a fizzy cream soda iced coffee! Their regular espresso-based drinks are also delicious. 

I've also heard great things about the baked goods but haven't personally tried them myself. My friends rave about the scones and the muffins. 

Definitely head to Andytown when you're in the sunset for a charming and homey coffee shop experience that will make you wish it was morning-time all the time! 

Happy Drinking, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
I must admit, I came in with pretty high expectations. I had heard things like "Their coffee is AMAZING" or "Andytown is my favorite coffee shop in the city", so I knew this place was no joke. Still, I wanted to see and judge for myself.

I ventured into Andytown's narrow storefront one Friday afternoon after brunch at Outerlands a couple blocks away, and I was immediately attracted to the big windows, clean aesthetic, and flowers that adorned the counter and the teeny tiny tables attached to the wall. I ordered a cappuccino (my go-to coffee drink) and stared at the pastry display even though I had just eaten because they all looked SO good. I contemplated getting the Snowy Plover just because it's something unique to Andytown, but I had tried an espresso + tonic water before and wasn't a huge fan, so I wasn't sure if I was gonna like that. I might come again just to try that though, because I noticed a tub of the homemade cream and it just looked so yummy haha. They serve hot drinks in the cutest ceramic mugs, which was so much fun to drink out of and made the whole experience seem so luxurious. I'm happy to say that I do think the coffee lived up to the hype; my cappuccino was delicious!

I also wanted to note that I LOVE that they use a manual lever espresso machine. Seeing them do things the "old fashioned" way just made me like this place even more. Keep it up, Andytown!
author: Sabrina C.

description: Five stars is given based on the customer service.  I didn't like the Snowy Plover; it tasted strange to me.  I was looking for something different and I'm glad that I tried it because a person can miss a lot of great things if they're afraid to step out of their comfort zone.  I usually like the 'different' things I try, but not this time.  I will go back the next time I'm in the area and am looking forward to something awesome.
author: Paul P.

description:
Loved it. And that's not just because they had tiny dinosaurs to play with in one of their larger potted cacti plants on the tables. 

Their offerings are refined, limited to just the right amount of choices (we've all heard about the jam experiment and how too many choices make us unable to choose, right?). Even the most simple daily brew of coffee is fantastic. Have it with a muffin, or one of their more Irish offerings  - I'd never thought I'd see farls outside of Sainsbury's or other UK locations!

I was able to do work here, but this is one of those places that are better spent with a friend, engaging in conversation and interacting with those around you. The space is small and you can expect a line even at random times of the day (a pretty positive sign of how alluring this place is, even in the Outer Sunset), but it moves quickly. 

Stop by if you're in the area. You're not going to regret it.
author: Ruoxi Y.

description: Great coffee. The location is ideal in the foggy sunset, for good, roasted coffee. I even like their snacks and sweets..
author: Jason P.

description:
Loved my tea au lait and soda bread with butter :) simple and perfect!

The wheaten bread is super soft and hearty sliced bread. They generously butter the bread and sprinkled flaked sea salt on top. Simple and perfect. 

The farl soda bread is more like a little bun sliced, buttered, and salted. Simple and perfect. :)
author: Jacquee P.

description: Cappuccino was the perfect mixture of bitter and earthy and with no weird aftertaste that some coffees have. Wasn't a fan of the snowy plover which others really enjoyed here but that's because it was too creamy for me and I don't like heavy coffees. Lots of sun and a cute atmosphere but can get crowded and can be hard to find a seat.
author: Theodora C.

description:
Quaint little Lawton corner. Parisian outdoor seating. Coffee does the trick! The mocha was just right. Slightly sweet, not sugary. Mostly taste the richness of the coffee bean. Once the beverage was consumed, there was no syrupy brown remanance to line the cup. True artisan coffee. For such a petite size it packed an astute punch. 

The snowy plover is Andytown's headliner. Ice, pelligrino, espresso and a dollop of whipped cream. The ultimate sunny beach day, caffeinated delight. The person who invented this drink must have been hungover with a killer stomach ache in need of a refreshing beverage. Unusual and satisfying. 

I was lucky enough to score one of the last strawberry cornbread muffins. It was better than I had anticipated. The top was a crusty golden brown with crispy edges and fresh lump strawberries inside. The cheddar, scallion scone was equally delicious. Possibly the best scone I've ever had. Savory and moist with a slightly crunchy exterior. I could taste the quality and handcrafted love in every bite. 

There was something authentically kind in the gentlemen making the espresso. A mellow mood you rarely see in this city anymore. Despite the queue, the interaction could easily be classified as a chill, non rushed experience. Maybe it was the fog rolling in or the fact that it is was weekday morning but still an infrequent occurrence  nonetheless. Pleasantly memorable in every way.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
I stopped into Andytown with my friend a while ago (delayed posting) and have to write a quick and to the point review to let you know that the Snowy Plover, is excellent.  I enjoyed it.   Granted, I had it at 3:30 in the afternoon, so I was wired the rest of the evening cleaning my apartment.  Definitely a stop in if you are in SF or near the area at the beach.  Though, I would probably recommend a hot drink if you are going to be outside. 

The butternut squash scone I split with my friend was also super delicious.  

Everything here is recommended!
author: J B.

description: What can I say?.. This place change my bake and coffee concept!, it's the best coffee shop I've ever been, the baked good are so simple but just delicioso in any way!, natural, so fresh, but so light and tasty I mean who knew corn meal could be so delicious! The coffee was a great or prefect complement to the baked goods!
author: Ana G.

description:
Andytown is one of my favorite coffee shops  in the city! Highly recommended. During the week, the shop is quiet and slow, on the weekend, there's a line out the door (never too bad). Andytown is tiny, it's definitely not the type of place to hang out with your computer or in a large group. It's sunny, small, cute and delicious. 

Andytown is small, but I love finding a table outside to enjoy my snowy plover. The drink has espresso, sparkling water (tonic/ sparkling?) and a large homemade dollop of whipped cream. The whipped cream at Andytown is heavenly, I'm not sure what crack they put in it. The snowy plover is so refreshing I can't order anything else here, although their cappuccinos look great. 

My favorite pastry here is the strawberry corn muffin - it's sort of a hybrid cornbread/ muffin with fresh strawberries inside. Last time I was here I also tried the jalapeño cheddar corn muffin, which was also great.
author: Lauren G.

description:
Andytown can definitely be seen as a very popular place - I've passed this cafe at varying times from opening to close, and it seems to be filled with people hanging out and taking a break from their busy lives. I decided to have a spontaneous visit for the first time this morning, and was greeted by the super friendly staff, and met some wonderfully friendly regulars as well. The place itself is a bit narrow, with limited seats inside, but there's plenty of seating outside. 

I have yet to try Andytown's famous snowy plover, but instead opted for a mocha and one of their soda breads, which comes out to about $9. My order came pretty quickly, and tasted absolutely amazing!! The mocha is very smooth, blended perfectly, and my soda bread (farl with butter I think) was extremely tasty. I can definitely see why the place is so well known, and it's almost certain I'll visit this place again!
author: Cindy N.

description: Finally made it to one of the "must try" coffee shops in SF for the coffee drink that put them on the map, the Snowy Plover. Unfortunately, it was a wasted trip and Lincoln. The drink, while unique and innovative, fell flat on its face despite the bubbly sparkling water. It was sour, and I seriously wondered if the cream spoiled. The tummy didn't complain so it's probably the subpar coffee they used that gave it the unpleasant sour notes. Disappointing.
author: S C.

description:
Great coffee, delicious scones! 

Tried the Snowy Plover and it definitely lived up to expectations. I'm a fan of Americanos and I found the sparkling water twist was especially refreshing. The whipped cream adds a really nice creaminess to the drink.

Tried the 2 scones; both were light and moist.
Cheddar Scallion 
Strawberry Chocolate chip (not too sweet!)
author: Jeany K.

description: I love this coffee shop! I'm not one to fall into SF's hipster coffee shop trend but I think this one stands out. One, it's location is in the outer sunset. And two, they've created a drink that stands out from the mint mojitos and blue bottles. The snowy plover is a must try! It's the perfect afternoon pick me up on a sunny afternoon. It's a carbonated coffee drink with a huge glop of cream in it. Mix it all together and it's delish!
author: Dara S.

description: Delicious coffee! The baristas clearly care about crafting a perfect cup, every time. Pastries/bread was delicious as well. Loved the industrial, modern interior.
author: Holly G.

description: very beautiful little coffee place in a great neighborhood. their fresh baked bread is so tasty. love to start my day off with some email checking while sipping a Latté
author: Erik S.

description:
Ohhh such a good espresso!!! By far the snowy plowder its my favourite, so simple but so tasty!
Once they got me waiting like 20 minutes for an iced tea(yeah, a tea), but besides that everything cool. Nice location and coffee. Nice to have this coffee shop in the neighborhood.
author: Claudio L.

description: Amazing espresso and that whipped cream is too die for!! Make sure your try the BlackBerry corn muffin with a pocket of sweet goat cheese in the center!
author: Jordan R.

description:
I thought philz was the breadwinner until I tasted some of Andytown's bread and coffee. Jalapeño cornbread is to die for. Almond milk latte is my go to but every other option is amazing. Don't forget that strawberry cornbread with fresh strawberries inside. 

My suggestion is going early specially on the weekends because they stop making the jalapeño cornbread after so many batches and there is a line out the door that you'd rather not wait in.
author: Kristoff F.

description:
Andytown is #1 on my list of my favorite coffee shops. I always get their almond milk latte, they are to die for. I've had almond milk lattes at other places where they use the same almond milk and it just does not compare. I truly believe that it tastes so fantastic because it's made with love! 

Sounds corny, I know. But when you are there, the staff is so nice and truly genuine, it's an experience every time. 

You cannot leave here without also getting a pastry!! I have had their muffins, scones, and soda bread. What makes the muffins so delicious is the cornmeal! 

The shop itself is a hole in the wall. You can stay and enjoy your drink and pastry but with not much seating available, I mostly take it to go. 

I tend to go to Andytown almost every weekend but I wish I could go more frequently!
author: Cierra Z.

description:
It's okay. 

Regarding the Snowy Plover: I think if soda water mixed with coffee were a great idea, a lot of places would serve it. Most places have access to both of these things.
author: Masha S.

description: This is hands down my favorite coffee shop in SF. First of all, the modern and cozy space gets me inspired, the almond lattes are the best I've ever had, the food is unique and amazing (corn bread berry muffins) and the staff is super awesome and friendly. I go here when I have the chance to work or to grab a snowy plover on a warm day after the beach. Beach views, awesome atmosphere and great people. The Outer Sunset has a great community and this coffee shop truly represents that.
author: Brittany N.

description:
Let me preface this to say I am by no means a coffee aficionado, but I do enjoy a sweet cup every now and then. 

I'd heard about Andytown and its infamous Snowy Plover and decided to give it a whirl.  As others have described, it's Pellegrino and espresso topped with a dollop of whipped cream.  I was very skeptical of the drink; I'm already not a fan of sparkling water, so I'm not sure what I expected.  I think it's basically a drink that you either love or hate, and unfortunately I fell into the latter camp.

We also tried the mocha, and while we liked the chocolate-y-ness of it, it lacked any coffee flavor, so just resembled more of a hot cocoa.

I really really wanted to like this place with its friendly workers and super cute space, but perhaps I'll just have to settle for their pastries.
author: Mel T.

description:
Perfect. Coffee. Shop. 

Wifi? Check! Unpretentious but fabulous coffee? Ch ch check! Glorious ambiance? Check it, fools! Super nice and skilled baristas? SO MANY CHECKS! 

I live in Cole Valley but will definitely be making the trek out here to this oasis of kind coffee-makers and tasty treats.
author: Adele A.

description: Coffee here was amazing! I really enjoyed the snowy plover. Be prepared for a line as they are quite busy. Came here too late the first time for their soda bread 10:30 am but was lucky enough the next time when I got there around 8:30 am. I really enojyed their scones, definitely recommend.
author: Samantha K.

description:
Fresh baked soda bread is very tasty. 

Snowy Plover is tasty and refreshing. 

And the coffee is fantastic.
author: Chase C.

description:
The gentleman at "The Coffee Shop" (it's actually called that) on Mission and Cesar Chavez who I think makes some of the best coffee in town said Andytown was his favorite place for their Snowy Plover and I can see why. It's espresso, soda water, and some really extraordinary fresh cream. It tastes so much like a soda that it's hard not to drink the whole thing in less than two minutes. Which is kinda rough cause they're $4 a pop. But it's very worth it. 

ProTip: Grab your cup to go and drink it at the beach
author: Misha T.

description: Snowy plover... my indulgence there! Oh don't forget to get their bread with bacon and cheddar!
author: J W.

description:
Andytown is a cute, small, hipster coffee shop. It is a little more expensive here than other small coffee shops, but I like to think I'm supporting a local, small business. 

Andytown is the perfect place to catch up with friends you haven't seen in awhile. There are tables outside that seat up to four people, and smaller tables inside that seat two. There's also a group table for larger parties, but it seems to always be in use by individuals. There's a bathroom in the back should you need one. 

I recommend the lattes and corn muffins. Both are absolutely the best options here, in my opinion!
author: Joanne K.

description: Andytown is a cute little coffee shop, but I do think it's overpriced. I tried their Snowy Plover the first time - a little too different for me, but their other coffee drinks are good.
author: Kelsey F.

description:
I was on my way to Marin from South Bay on a beautiful Saturday morning and decided to take a quick coffee break in San Francisco. Given the sheer amount of coffee shops in the area, I wanted to go somewhere that differentiated from the typical fairly-traded, shade-grown, small-batch-roasted pour over or latte that I usually get. Thanks to Yelp, I found the Snowy Plover. I was able to get a wonderful glimpse of the ocean before I managed to park my car amidst a sea of other Andytown patrons.

The shop itself was pretty small; there was only enough seating for 3-4 small groups of people. The ambiance was very laid-back, with corner window facing the seascape ahead. The baristas, while very quick, were great at delivering service without sacrificing quality.

I had already eaten my breakfast for the day, so I just ordered the $4 Snowy Plover. I was pretty impressed with the breakfast menu, though, as Andytown does offer a variety of savory options on top of the typical coffee shop pastry offerings. The soda bread and cheese offered on the menu also pleasantly evoked nostalgic memories of northern Europe...

So, to the Snowy Plover. Great drink. I was surprised at how delicious it was. The drink is basically a mixture of ice, a couple shots of espresso, simple syrup, S. Pellegrino sparkling water, and house-made unsweetened whipped cream. The sparkling water did a great job of enhancing the flavor of the espresso and the cream tied up the flavor beautifully at the end. I also found that the foam formed by the cream and sparkling water created an unintended artistic effect.

Great experience to have, and I think it was worth the stop and money to give this unique shop a try. I would come back if I come back to the neighborhood.
author: Dianna D.

description: This place is so good! My first time was the other day I had a latte. The service was really good which is also why I will be back. Very friendly and fast
author: Chelsea O.

description:
Super cute place with nice decor and homey ambiance. There's not many seating options so I suggest just taking your coffee to go. I got the snowy plover and espresso con panna, the whipped cream they use for both is amazing alone. The snowy plover is interesting but I suggest just trying it if you never had it before. 

They also have really good pastries made in house and free doggy treats by the door!
author: Kay K.

description:
There are a lot of shitty things about the outer Sunset, mainly being in the middle of nowhere. There are a few perks and gems here and there, but Andytown is definitely the shining star in my book.
Bright little neighborhood joint with friendly service. I've been told that Lauren and Michael (the owners) are ex Blue Bottle employees. Let me just say that this tells me that they know their shizz when it comes to a good cuppa.

First, let me talk about the space. It's small. There's a big communal table in the front, then I think 3 little doubles tables (outlets under so you can charge your electronics) along the narrow hall. More tables and chairs outside, including a bench right out front. It's a neighborhood joint so it doesn't get too crowded. Sometimes the line looks long (out the door) but it moves fast. What can I say? These folks know how to make coffee! It's very well lit inside, lots of natural sunlight. I enjoy that a lot. Fresh floral arrangements weekly. 

Pastries - I've only had their corn muffins. Each time I come, they just happen to bring some piping hot out the oven. I always get suckered by these. I LOVE THEM. First it was the peach goat cheese corn muffin, then I had some sort of strawberry one but yesterday's fig and orange compote corn muffin might have been my favorite. They are huge. I can never finish one on my own. I haven't tried any other pastry. 

My favorite drink is the Snowy Plover. The first time I came in here, Lauren explained to me what it was. She told me if you're a coffee lover, you're either gonna love it or hate it. Well, I'm an open minded individual and I LOVE COFFEE so.... I ended up loving it. 2 shots of espresso with ice, Pellegrino, brown sugar and homemade whipped cream. My gawd, I just sold my soul to the Devil. As Jyang says "COFFEE SODA!" but whatever, I LOVES ITTTTTT. 2 beautifully pulled strong espresso shots and Pellegrino, who would've thunk? Not me that's for sure. It makes for a great drink on a hot day (especially since it's been effing humid) but it's just a solid drink all around, during any weather. It's like a great strong cup of iced coffee with a little zing (from the Pellegrino) that lightens it up a bit. The piece de resistance is definitely the homemade whipped cream. I have to say that I hate whipped cream from the can. Homemade is the shiznitz and let me tell you... The first day I stepped into Andytown, Lauren gave me a healthy helping of that delectable cream on my first Snowy. Never looked back...Well, except to check their store hours. DAMMIT they close at 3pm and they're closed on Mondays. I swear if they opened up earlier than 7am, I would drive my arse down to Andytown for my fix prior to hauling arse to work.

So yeah... just sign on the dotted line. Your soul? Donezo.
author: Susy C.

description:
My favorite coffee shop in San Francisco, hands down. I'm tempted to not add my review so I don't add to the already-long lines, but, eh, what's one more 5-star review going to do.

The drinks and food they serve have simple but high-quality ingredients - and it all tastes delicious. Plain and simple. 

For us, going to Andytown is more of an event in itself then something we race through; instead of saying "Let's grab a coffee before we do x, y, and z," we normally say  "Let's go to Andytown."
author: Jacob N.

description:
I thought this place was ok.
I wanted to try something different so got the snowy plover which is carbonated coffee with whipped cream.  I wasn't a fan.
The carbonation took getting used to.

The espresso was sour that day and I'm no coffee/espresso snob but my one requirement is for coffee/espresso to not have that sour taste.
author: Heejin L.

description:
This is one of those hidden gems, located in the Outer Sunset district of San Francisco. They're absolutely one of a kind and continue to hold up their reputations of being one of the coffee shops, if not the best, in the City. 

Decor is very homey, but modern at the same time, it provides a nice bright environment. Seating is limited, but the menu and staff make up for it.

They're scones and corn muffins are always super fresh! And the ingredients they use for their baked goods complement each other. The apple, cinnamon, ginger scone, is a staff favorite, according to the shop, and I can't blame them for loving it! The ginger bits in the warm, soft scone really go well with the apple and cinnamon. 

I always get a Snowy Plover, and it's 1 shot of espresso with brown sugar simple syrup, and sparkling water,  topped off with this AMAZING whipped cream! [ I always ask for extra whip!] Of course, it takes some getting used to, but it grows on you, just like the staff, instantly! 

Service and staff, will make you feel like home and are always in positive and friendly vibes. They'll talk to you as if they'd known you all their life and share funny and amusing stories with you.

The 'master Barista', is super nice! And her latté art skills are Spot.On. 
They have a new seasonal scone: pumpkin and chocolate; I was skeptical, but I was proved wrong. Both worked so great with each other!
author: Milli M.

description: What a great place, felt like old San Francisco, not the Millennium Crowd like in the Mission. Coffee very good, eat a super Strawberry Corn Muffin and my friend had a Soda Black Currant Scone with a drink called Snowy Plover (named after a local Ocean bird). Before you go there visit the beach close by. Part of the total experience.
author: Johann F.

description:
Snowy Plover?!?! SNOWY PLOVER?!? SNOWY PLOVER?!?! Drive across town and make us Come oVER?!?!?! 

Susy C. was ranting and raving about this place and seeing as JY is a huge coffee drinker we had to check it out. However, seeing is that I don't drink coffee or give two shits about coffee I'm probably not the best critic of this place. However, appreciated the wide variety of scones, the relatively short line, and the SF ambiance. 

Snowy Plover = Coffee Soda. 

Happy trails. 

J to the Y.
author: Justin Y.

description:
Cute and hip cafe and best of all within walking distance. This place is always crowded, line is always out the door.

Their corn muffins are good. I've had the jalapeño cheddar  (good kick), strawberry  (decent, buttery), Apple & raspberry jam pocket (very very sweet).

Lattes are good. They use clover milk and make cute designs. 

Snowy Plover - possibly the worst thing I've ever tasted in my mouth. It is their only cold brew coffee made with soda water (tonic water?) with an ice cream scoop of heavy cream on top. The cream is good but the coffee itself was disgusting.

I like coming here just for the corn muffins and latte.
author: Terry D.

description:
I was torn what to order here because everyone raves about the Snowy Plover (an iced drink - someone super creative must've thought it up - it's sparking water + espresso + homemade whipped cream), but it was so cold I wanted a warm drink.  I had a couple sips of my friend's Snowy Plover and while it was good at first, I can't see myself finishing the whole thing.  I could taste the acidity of the coffee more when mixed with sparking water and I wasn't really a fan.  

I ended up with a latte and I much preferred that - it was delicious.  The coffee roast is just the way I like it  - dark and rich.  I'm not a fan of super acidic coffee so I'm glad that wasn't the case here.  The coffee art is fun to see too!  Well crafted coffee and delicious scones.  Definitely give this place a try!
author: Angela C.

description: Came here everyday before the commute to BottleRock Festival with a friend. SOOOO SOOO GOOD! First off, the ambience is nice. Very beautifully curated space. Also, the coffee and pastries are great. Just simple goodness. They make all the pastries and bread on site, huge bonus in my book. They can tell you exactly what's in everything. The drinks are perfect. I got a mocha and it was amazing. Nothing short of what I expected. Customer service was exemplary as well.
author: Tati N.

description:
Food
* The Snowy Plover was so weird. The idea of carbonated coffee made me skeptical and tasting it confirmed my skepticism. 
* The sausage roll was sooooo greasy!!! Blech! The flavor was overpowering
* Mocha was good! Can't mess that up :)

Service
The staff was welcoming, kind, and smiling! Always a nice touch

Ambiance
Outdoor seating and awkward 1-2 person seating indoors in a very narrow walkway.

Overall
Perhaps this is just not my scene. I am not a coffee aficionado, which may take away from the review's credibility, but Andytown has not won my heart. I'm not sure what it is with the obsession with uncommon, quirky coffee shops, but I have had better experiences elsewhere.
author: Marjo M.

description:
If only the mochas we're tastier I'd have gone for the full 5 stars. I like the ambiance and usually the food is really good too, but their mochas never hit the spot. A little too bitter I guess? I'm not a fan of sweet mochas, but c'mon these don't even taste like 90% cacao chocolate, it just tastes like a latte with a tiny shake of Hershey's cocoa.

I don't like carbonated beverages but my boyfriend LOVES the snowy plover, and they never seem to mess that up, so I guess if you want a unique, fizzy, iced coffee drink you should for sure try that. 

Finally, I've heard they used to have some amazing sausage rolls but don't anymore. I'm praying those return and I can revise this review based on the amazingness I've heard about those! For now, get the soda bread if you're hungry (it's a 9/10 in my book).
author: Emmi B.

description:
I've admired Andytown from afar for awhile now, what with its gorgeous dark blue exterior and inviting outdoor seating. Today I stopped in for the first time and my already-high expectations were still surpassed.

Andytown ups the cool points of the Outer Sunset by like a thousand. Cute rustic-yet-modern decor, friendly hipster staff, delicious fare -- honestly, this is such a neighborhood gem.

I had a cappuccino with almond milk which was s-t-r-o-n-g. Food options are limited to pastries (mainly gluten-free corn muffins of both the savory and sweet variety) as well as a seasonal open-face sandwich -- I ordered the latter which today happened to be basil pesto and tomato on soda bread.

Everything tasted light, fresh and delicious. Best of all, fellow nut-allergy sufferers rejoice: Andytown is a NUT-FREE kitchen (with the exception of the almond milk; FYI I'm only allergic to pecans and walnuts). Wooooooot!

Will definitely be back, maybe not on the hottest day of the year next time, so I can linger around for longer.
author: Tiffany W.

description: So good! Snowy plover is definitely something to try, although I wish they had the cream without sugar as an option- I think the drink ends up being a little sweet. Baked goods are to die for!
author: Masha B.

description: How do you make things right?  When you did something wrong, when someone has done you wrong, when you wake up on the wrong side of the bed. The answer is not easy.  But Andytown Coffee Roasters is a good start. This little place that can, does, and does it well. A sip of snowy plover, a bite of the cheddar jalapeno corn muffin, and all is good again, atleast for the moment...
author: Vin A.

description:
Is it a crime to be more excited about the warm blueberry corn muffins than the actual coffee? Because they are that good. So delectable, so warm and with the perfect chewy texture only corn meal has. The muffins bursts with subtle sweetness of the ripened berries, and the coffee a perfect hot pairing on a cold day. 

If you are up for adventure, try the snowy plover. That is basically iced carbonated coffee. They use pellegrino and espresso and ice to make this drink. Not quite my favorite or a favorite at all, but an interesting concept that's both creative and unique. Their hot lattes and capps are great. Bonus: they have almond milk!

On a different subject, andytown has 5 stars! That's rare for yelp. I wish them continued success and I encourage new concepts even if it's a strange concoction of espresso and soda water. I will be back again. And again.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Coffee is SO GOOD! This place is small, very intimate- with one community table in the front. But for its small size- it gets BUSY but stays organized. Lines out the door with cyclists mid morning. Early mornings are great though (6a-8:30a would be ideal) but don't worry the rushes are quick. They make these wonderful breads and spreads that smell enticing, I do wish they offered a vegan and gf option though! They also have an impressive tea selection!
I'm still going for the amazing baristas and quality coffee!
author: Jessica B.

description: This has become a mandatory daily stop every morning. Far and away the best coffee I've ever had. You will also find great food items to choose from.
author: Stephen M.

description: The space is a bit cramped (partly because they're so popular), but the food (soda bread with butter, cheddar and bacon), coffee (the Snowy Plover) and service were all A+.
author: Richie T.

description:
We came by for a little pre-brunch pick-me-up.  
Ordered: Cheddar Scallion Scone, Snowy Plover (wow!), & an Almond Latte. Holy shit, they hit everything out of the park! 
When we arrived the line was long but moved quickly. 

The staff is awesome and actually looks you in the eye when you speak to them, always very refreshing. 

The ambiance is great; serious 'feel good' vibes.
Thank you Andytown! We'll be back for more.
author: Mack B.

description: Carbonated coffee has changed my life. Get the snowy plover! Worth the travel to try (if you like fizzy drinks lol)
author: V L.

description:
This place is so delightful. The service is always amazing and their drinks are fantastic. It's right next to the beach (about four blocks or so) so I always pick up a Snowy Plover and a Soda Farl Bread for breakfast and walk down to the beach to start my Sunday mornings. 

There's not much space that a typical cafe has to study or do work but there is a community table where you have more space than not. There's no plugs for outlets so it's not an ideal space do work but it's awesome to read a book outside on the outdoor seating or have a chat with a friend. 

This place is by far one of my favorite coffee places in the city.
author: Aleesa B.

description: I do not know what makes Andytown Coffee the best coffee in the city. Maybe this is the nice people who's working there or maybe small and cozy interior in quite neighborhood but there is definitely some hidden magic what makes every cup of coffee tasty and memorable.
author: Dmitry G.

description:
So this review is wayyyyy overdue. I came here for the first time a while back with my sister and we decided to try Andytown's special snowy plover. It was very interesting at first and then suddenly BAM! It just came on to us and before we knew it, we were hooked and couldn't stop drinking it! 

Since then I come here every now and then to treat myself. The snowy plover, mocha, and lattes are all winners! but let's not forget about ALL of their muffins and soda/wheaten bread!!! My bf is straight up out of Ireland and he agrees that this Irish-like coffee shop is pretty legit!
author: Michelle L.

description: Small, simple, great coffee. A few small personal tables and a group table inside, with a few tables outside. Wifi available. Expect a line out the door but it won't be longer than 10-15 min. Worth the wait! Get the snowy plover! So unique and so good!
author: Nicholas M.

description: Got a cappuccino to go, kinda small but cute with the milk.  The Mr got a snowy plover to go ... it was okay, not feeling the soda water taste.  DEF must from this place is the jalapeño cheddar corn muffin.  Wanted to go back for another but the line was too long.  Also got this pear jam corn muffin?  I forgot what it was but that was delicious too!  The crust alone on the muffins was good but ya gotta get a full bite of everything to know how good it is.  Place is pretty small inside with one large table in the front and some singles along the side and back.  There's some outside seating too, maybe two tables?  I will definitely come back for the muffins!
author: enygma g.

description:
Why do I always follow the hype?! Oh my, oh my, ohh my.... 

Walked in around noon, first impression - what a cute cafe! Wished the space was bigger to accommodate more people inside. I can't imagine when the cafe is busy on a rainy day. People will definitely be lining out the door!

Of course, I had to order the most hyped drink, the Snowy Plover. A bit of carbonated water, espresso and topped with their homemade wiped cream. What does it taste like? Just think soda, but coffee flavored. It's different, but not WOWing.

The BEST part was the Scallion & Cheddar Scone! Smelled it first and I was salivating before I even took my first bite! It's crispy on the outside, but warm and soft on the inside! I think they used cornmeal in for it??? Whatever it is, it was delicious! If I were to be in the neighborhood, I'll definitely be ordering at least a dozen of these! (Alright, I won't be selfish. Maybe only 3 since I don't have a big enough stomach to eat a dozen....).
author: Jane C.

description: Delicious scones, got the cheddar scallion and a fruity one I don't remember. One of them were slightly burned but still delicious. Great cappuccinos and americanos. Ginger tea was also delicious, something my boyfriend ordered since he had a sore throat. The place is very tiny however so good luck finding a seat. There are about 3 tables on the side of the building,
author: Yoomi C.

description:
Andytown is one of those coffee shops where you're going to have to wait in line for. It's extra tiny inside and there doesn't seem to be a lot of available seats. I went on a Sunday morning and it was packed inside and out..with a line out the door even with the rain. 

As you can probably already tell from all the reviews, the snowy plover is the thing to get if you're trying this place out for the first time. I've had a rendition of the snowy plover elsewhere and I did not like at all. But after trying Andytown's snowy plover, I'm in love with this combination! I'd say the whipped cream on top (and maybe partially the espresso) makes it THE Andytown snowy plover. I will come back to try the soda bread and for another snowy plover!!!!
author: Ingrid C.

description:
There are SO many things to love about this place.  For starters, it's a beautiful store.  It's right on the corner of Lawton and 43rd with a big corner window.  The interior is tastefully done with a beachy Outer Sunset vibe.  The staff is incredibly friendly.  Lauren and Sandra, two of the baristas there, are just sweethearts.

I usually get a mocha or a snowy plover and they're both as delicious as reviews here say they are.  Their in-house baked goods are also some of the best pastries in town.  There is no lack of consistency here. I love getting the black currant scones.  The pastries are always perfect.  Every.  Single.  Time.

It's just fantastic to have a local neighborhood shop that fits in seamlessly with the neighborhood and doesn't feel like some chain that's been dropped in.  I highly recommend people search out this place.

I only have two slight minuses and it's more to do with how popular the place is.  I wish it were a wee bit bigger to accommodate more indoor seating, although there's plenty of outdoor seating.  It's also not uncommon to find a line out the door.  It's that popular.

Still, those are minor quibbles that do not detract at all from the incredibly positive impression one gets when visiting.
author: Gordon A.

description:
I cannot get enough of this place and wish they opened longer hours. It's pretty far out but so worth the trip. I have serious cravings each week for their Snowy Plover and scones. 

Snowy Plover - you'll have to try it for yourself, this drink is SINFUL. I'm not a fan of whipped cream and I don't usually order a lot of iced drinks, but love theirs (homemade) on top of my espresso w/ sparkling water. I've had a similar drink at both Saint Franks in Russian HIll and Front in Potrero Hill. Not nearly as amazing as Andytown. What do you guys put in this thing?! Whoa.
